Play details
Madd couple well matcht. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1653. Date first performed: 1637-1639?
The Persons of the Comedy.
Carelesse, a young wilde Heire. Sir Val. Thrivewell, his Unkle that adopted him Heire. Saleware, a Citizen and a Cuckhold. Saveall, Sir Valentines demure Steward. L. Lovely, a wencher. Bellamy, a woman disguised, and his Steward. Wat, a blunt fellow, Carelesses Servingman. Old Bellamy. Lady Thrivewell. Mrs. Alicia, Salewares light wife Mrs. Crostill, a rich Vintners Widow, and humorous. Phoebe, Carelesse his Whore. Closet, an old Crone, Nursekeeper to L. Thrivewell. Apprentices. Servingmen. And Attendants.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Alicia Saleware Bellamy George Careless Saveall Saleware L. Lovely Wat Thrivewell Page Phoebe Mrs Crostill Lady Thrivewell Old Bellamy Prentice Nurse Closet Prologue/Epilogue Seervant Fitzgerald Combined speech

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.p: Here you are all met, and look for a set speech, Put into Rhyme, to court you, and beseech Your Worships, but to hear and like the Play, But I, I vow, have no such part to say. I am sent a wooing to you, but how to do it, I have not the skill; it is true I have a new Suite, And Ribbons fashionable, yclipped Fancies, But for the Complements, the Trips, and Dances, Our Poet cannot abide um, and he swears, They are all but cheats; and sugared words but jeers. He is harkening there: and if I go about To make a Speech, he vows, he will put me out. Nor dare I write to you: therefore in this condition, I will turn my courtship into admonition. When a good thing is proffered, do not be nice, Our Poet vows, you shall not be proffered twice.

div2.stage: ACT. I. SCENE. I. Carlesse, Wat.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou hast delivered my Letter?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes Sir, to Master. Saveall your Uncles friend: But he has stood your friend so long, and so often, to so little purpose in moving your Uncle for you, that he holds it utterly in vain, to urge him any further, he told me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou shouldest have told him, I would not be so answered.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes; and then he would have told me, let your Master take his course.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Then you should have told him again, I have taken all the courses I could, or as any Gentleman can to maintain myself like one; But all my courses are run out, and I have not breath, nor know any ground whereon to begin a new one, unless that thing my Uncle sets me
up again, nor have I any means to attain to that, but by his Mediation.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Then would he have told me again, what all your courses have been. Namely, running into debt by all the ways can be imagined, and cheating by all could be invented, then that the said thing, (as you call it) your Uncle, before he cast you quite off, had redeemed you out of Prison, and several holds, within the space of fifteen Months fourteen times.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That was not once a Month then, or if it had, what had that been to him? it was I that suffered, thou shouldest have told him, not he.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: He would have told me then again, That several Redemptions, cost your Uncle at least two thousand pound And that upon your last revolt when he quite gave you over for a castaway, two years since, he cast the third thousand with you, upon condition never to afflict him more. And then he Married in hope to get an heir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Aye that Marrying spoiled all.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Because you should not after his death cast away all the rest of the thousands, and ten thousands which you might have lived to inherit, if your Uncles love or Master. Savealls counsel could have prevailed with you against the Devil, and Debauchedness.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Pox on it, let it all go, let that wretched Uncle go, and let Saveall go for a punctual ass as he is. I confess he has by his saving help pieced me with my Uncle a score of times at least. What had once more been to him?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Sir, it were better for you to think upon some course by ourself, and me your Creature (that have stuck to you, or followed you through all fortunes) to maintain Rich Lace, and Bravery upon you. And think in time too before this be worn out, upon some new ways for your supplies

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I cannot, nor will I trouble my brains to think of any, I will rather die here in Ram alley, or walk down to the Temple, and lay myself down alive, in the old Synagogue, cross-legged among the Monumental Knights there, till I turn Marble with them. Think quoth he! what should I think on?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: On your poor Whore Sir (as you have brought her) she is in worse case than yourself; your Clothes are good enough

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Aye there is the Devil. I would do something for her if I knew how. But what have I not done that can be done by a forlorn heir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Why though the Dice, and all other Household games, and all the Cheats belonging unto them have failed you by your and their discoveries, till none dare venture so near you as a Man hurls a Die or Skirts a Card. Though all your hidden ways in Hyde park races are trod out, and all your bowling booties beaten bare off of the Grounds and Allies; and the sweet Honeycombs of all your Cockpit cozenages cut off. Though all your Arts of borrowing are crossed out of all Men's Books before you offer at them, while your old Debts stand fairly written, and all your Marts miscarry of putting out for credit, Venison to Citizens, or early Cherries, Codlings and Apricots to their Wives avail you nothing, cannot something yet be found?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing. All Projects are confounded.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Did your Father leave you nothing but wit to live upon for this? And did he leave you that but for years, and not for Life? and is the term expired?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hold thy peace. I am casting for something to be done by me, that shall be worth, and cost my life, to shame my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
There is a plot! Think of your poor whore Sir,
how shall she live, if you cast away yourself?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I must leave her once thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: If you could leave her now, and betake yourself handsomely to other Women, I have thought on a course.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, quickly, what is it?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: To set up a Male bawdy house.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Fie upon it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You are handsome, lovely, and I think able to do one Man's work, two or three such Gentlemen more which I know, and can describe to you, with the ways I will find to bring in custom shall fill your purses

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And empt our bones. I ever had enough of one Mistress Variety would destroy me. No Gentlemen can be able to hold it out. They are too weak to make common He whores.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For a little while Sir, till we have got a stock of rich clothes; And then we will put Dray men, and Wine porters, Cornish Wrestlers and such like into those clothes; and make them Country Cavaliers. Have you not seen course snout-fair drudges, clapped into bravery, that would do more bodily service in a Brothel than twenty Ladies Daughters? They are the Game bears of a Bawdy-house, can play ten single courses for a clean bred Gentlewoman's one, we will hire fellows for groats a piece a day, that shall (without the additaments of Clary, Caudle or Cock-broth) get us forty pieces a Man before Night, or perhaps a hundred by next Morning, out of such she customers, as an Aunt of mine shall find out for us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O base Villain! No I will never fall so deep below a Gentleman, as to be Master of a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Very good decayed Gentlemen have done as much; though I urge this, but for your pastime sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No my first plot shall stand, I will do some notorious death deserving thing (though these clothes go to the Hangman for it, what care I) in defiance of him that was my Uncle, and his Methodical, Grave, and Orthographical speaking friend, Master. Saveall that calls People People.
O Master. Saveall how have you honoured me, how am I bound to you for this visit! Sir hearing that my Uncle was come to Town, and you with him, I did presume to write to you.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Send forth your Man.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Go forth

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: One Servant is not fit for all Offices, although you keep no more; you presumed indeed, I can no less than call it a presumption, although it were but unto me you write; I speak not this in the behalf of any dignity in me; but that you should overween that I had ability to wrestle any more with your overgrateful Uncle in your behalf. Therein was your outrecuidance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The miserablest Man on Earth! in having wearied out my worthiest friend, on whom the sum of all my hopes was cast.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: No, I am not wearied; But still in the same full strength: yet my modesty dissuadeth me from using strength above reason, and my reason prevaileth with me not to strive against a Torrent.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: He is then inexorable, and I must perish. But did you try him for me this last time?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I have both tried, and tempted him to his vexation.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But did you urge that pious act of mine Which he once vowed should never be forgot, Or unrewarded by him?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p:
Your standing upon merit in that Act Perplexeth nature in him, and confounds
Both your desert, and his benevolence, And now since you have urged it, I will tell you, Your Act was undeniable, most noble, And glorious in a Nephew, greater piety Could not have been expected in a Son: When from the Swords of Thieves and Murderers, Your valour rescued him But

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I and my Man I am sure made four of the stoutest purses fly for it, that ever set our Country of the score: After they had him down, and their points at his breast and throat, he crying out for help, when I came on by chance at a time too when I was in his displeasure, nay he hated me a whole year together before that, and yet I did it, and more than so

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Fare you well Sir, I thought to have said all this for you, and more than so too. But

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay sweet Master. Saveall

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Good Master. Careless, as I can hear I would be heard sometimes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Indeed I cry you mercy, pray sir speak.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I was commending of your act, and do so still. You did express yourself in blood and nature A perfect Kinsman; and your piety Drew blessings on you: for whereas before Your Uncle left you off to Reprobation, He then receives you a Son, (being his Sisters.) Adopted you, intended you his heir, And out of his Estate then presently Allowed you two hundred pounds per annum, And gave your Man for what he suffered In the conflict an hundred Marks

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Poor Rogue! and he deserved it, I will be sworn for a Thieves mark that he received; a cut of the Coxcomb that cracked his skull, so that he could never bear his drink since, as he could have done before. For sir, as we
came in, I having put by the thrusts of three of them, the fourth man with a full blow

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Fare you well Sir the second time

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay courteous Master. Saveall.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I came to speak not with you altogether, but unto you for to be heard.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir I will hear you with all due respect.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Your Uncle having done so gratefully, and so plentifully for you. You building still on merit for that service, Did hold him so fast bound that you presumed To run upon more extravagances In all the outweighs of debauchery, Till for the one good deed you did for him He did you forty, in restoring you From Surfeits, Wants, Wounds and Imprisonments, Till overborne with charge, and more with anguish, At your outrageous, unexampled Riots, He gave you an irrevocable farewell, yet then at your departure.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Yet then I lived and could have done till now, merely by being his Nephew, and supposed his heir, had not he married; but his Marriage turned the hearts of all believing Citizens from me, where before a Taylor could have made me run through all the credit in the Town,
When in a suit Chinquant, and A la mode They could inform themselves, whose heir I was, But to say truth I vexed him into Wedlock, for before he valued not a Wife at a bachelors Button.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Farewell to you the third time.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, you shall see me die first, and that instantly; That you may tell my Uncle I will be no more his trouble, or charge, unless in charity he will send to bury me.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: You will not desperately work a violent end upon yourself?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No Sir, the Devils not so great with me; but my heart, I feel it ready to break. My Uncle is no more my Uncle, nor you my friend, all by my own fault, and what should I do here, but in to my Bed, and out of the World presently. Wat. Wat.
Aye here Sir!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I have dallied too long, and tempted him too far I fear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Lay down my Bed.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Your Wench is come indeed, but I hope you will not to bed before he be gone.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Lay down my bed I say. But first unbutton me.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Lord how his heart beats! pangs of death I fear.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Not so I hope. I will now come to the point Sir, Master. Careless be comforted.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am, and well resolved, I thank my better Angel.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Your Uncle is friends with you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Alas, how can that be?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I thought your spirit had been higher.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It will be Sir anon, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I have but dallied with you to search your temper.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But you have searched too deep I fear sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Your Uncle is friends with you, I say so far as to make a further trial of your nature, you may be yet his heir; for your Aunt despaireth of any Child by him, having fruitlessly been married now these two years.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ah! But good Sir, can this be?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: It is, and I will bring you to him. And see that all be well.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your noble friendship hath revived me sir, O run and fetch my cloak.
Tell Phebe I cannot stay to give her any satisfaction now, I must go see my Uncle first.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman, how weakly he standeth! The sight of his Uncle will recover him. Come Master. Careless let us go.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir what do you think if I should first according to the reformation of my mind cut off my undecent hair, and change this garish apparel for a civil well worn Students suit, I can be fitted presently hard by.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: No, the mind reformed is enough, your habit well becommeth you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Now Wit if it be thy will go with him. And I hope this will be his last hot fit of the Uncle.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Your Masters gone forth it seems.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Called by his fortune, he is so.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Shuns he the sight of me? I will overtake him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: O your patience sweet Mistress Phebe, a little patience. He is gone to be happy, and to make you happy. I dare promise you a Satin Gown within this seven-night. For let me tell thee Mistress Phebe bright He is reconciled to his Uncle Knight.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Away Pimp, Flamsted, I came to be serious with him, to let him know the miseries I suffer, by the wrongs he has done me, and that I can nor will no longer bear them.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nor him neither will you? Take heed what you say Madam Marion.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: No not him neither, you panderly Parasite, till he make his vows good, and me an honest Woman.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Byrlady, a shrewd task, and I fear an impossible work.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Sirrah, I will claw your ugly Face till thou undertakest it with him, to make it easy.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I will do you all the good I can,

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: O will you so?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How desperately valiant a Whore grows, when she is so poor that her clothes fear no tearing. But by what means can you hope to bring this work about?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You know I have a wealthy Kinsman in the City.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: O Master. Saleware, and he has a Wife too that bears it up bravely.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Pimp impudent, shall I claw your Face into blushes at my injuries, to be mocked out of my Maidenhead, when I was upon a good Match in the Country; Then with a promise of Marriage, to be enticed from my friends into fools Paradise (that was a new title for the City) and here to be used, and abused from Lodging to Lodging, by him that now flies me, for the decays he hath brought me to? But my Kinsman has money though I have none, and for money there is Law to be found, and in a just cause he will not let me sink, he says: for I have told him all.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But not the how many times, the whens, the wheres, and the wherewithals, I hope have you?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Sirrah, I shall show you and your Master too a way to more civility, since I am thus abused, and slighted.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You have schooled me handsomely, and brought me into sense of your injuries: you have been over wronged, but not overwrought, nor overworn, you do excel in Beauty, Strength and Spirit, which makes you in your very anger now appear so lovely, that I profess myself your Creature. What would a kiss of this fair Hand now make me do, and of those Lips what not?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Away you Creature.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Leave these temptations; do not strike me too deeply in love with you.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Away you Creature.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: It is true I am your Creature, as I am my Masters; And sometimes the serving Creature, breaks his fast with a bit off the Spit before the same meat is served up to his Masters table, but is never denied to Dine upon his Masters leavings, you cannot think what an appetite that frown gives me.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You are no saucy Rascal.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Good wit too! My appetite needs no Sauce; nor shall you need to make use of Law, or Friend against my Master, but myself.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Be ruled by me, if I do not lay you down, and join with you presently in a course that shall content you, then hang me Lady at your door.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: In the next room we shall find Pen, Ink and Paper, you shall write him such a Letter (as I will dictate to you) that shall so nettle him.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Nay I did intend to leave him part of my mind in writing before I went.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: O Cousin, I want you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: A pox of this interrupting Cuckold, he hinders all Trading, but his Wives, 'swounds I was going with full speed a Tilt, as the learned say, had not this horn head come, we had writ lines together should have put down Hero and Leander Hark you Mistress Phebe, is this your Kinsman that you told me, you had told all the business to?

sp.speaker: Sale.
sp.p:
Yes, sir, I am the Gentleman, and she has told me so much, Sir that I must tell you, to tell your Master from me, and as I would tell him myself if he were here personally present, he is a most dishonest Gentleman if he do her not lawful right by Marrying her; and
that right I came to demand, and obtain of him, or to denounce the Law against him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How happy are you, that you came short to tell him so, else he would have so beaten you, as never was Citizen beaten, since the great Battle of Finsbury-Field.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Your great words cannot make me fear his blows (I am not dashed nor bashed) nor cross him out of my Book, for fear of any such payment. I have him there for four score pound as you know, though you are pleased to forget me, But Sapientia mea mihi stultitia tua tibi.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Cry mercy Master. Saleware, is it you? I hope Mistress Saleware is well, your most exquisite, and most courtly wife; the Flower-de-luce of the City.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Well wag well, you must not now put me off with my wife, she is well and much respected; I come to speak of, and for my distressed Kinswoman, her whom your wicked Master has most wickedly dealt withal. He has deflowered and deluc'd her, and led her from her Friends, and out of her Country into Fools Paradise By making her believe he would Marry her, and here he has put her on, and put her off, with hopes and delays till she is come to both woe and want; And (which may prove her most affliction, if he be suffered to forsake her) she is with child by him.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Say you so, Mistress Phebe? here is small show of it yet.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Sirrah, I shall show you and your Master too a way to more civility, if I be thus abused and slighted.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: By the way Master. Saleware, how many children have you by your most amiable wife?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Sir, that needs not to fall by the way of our discourse.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
But by the way I speak of getting children. Or
I pray tell me, did not you correct one of her children once, for which your wife reprehended you, and bad you correct your own? And how then shall my Master be sure that this (if it be one) is his?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: What an Asinego is this? I shall find a time sir, to talk with your Master. In the mean time I tell you that my Kinswoman is a Gentlewoman of as good blood as himself, and of the best in Herefordshire.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, Welsh blood.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And shall find friends that shall not see her abused by you nor him. There is Law to be found for money, and money to be found for Friends, and Friends to be found in the Arches, and so tell your Master, come away Cousin.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But one word before you go Sir, is this Gentlewoman, (who was but a Country Chambermaid when my Master took her to his mercy) of such boasted blood, your Cozen by your own, or by your Wives side I pray?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Sirrah, like a saucy companion as you are, though you meddle with me that am a Common councilman; I charge you meddle not with my wife, you have had two or three jerks at her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I was warned before Sir, in my own understanding: for she is for great persons.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Then know your distance Sir.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yet give me leave to wait you down Sir, cud shoe did it tell it Kinsman that it is got with Champkin.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You are a Panderly Rascal, and I will be a terror both to you, and your Patron.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How can you think so?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Think! I see it apparently upon your Face, and hear it in your sighs, your broken sleeps tonight, when your own groans waked you, declared no less;
But had I had the power of some wives with their husbands I could have fetched it out of you waking once (I thank you) you took me in your arm, but when you found it was I you turned away as in a dream.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Sure you dream now, whence can this talk proceed else?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I must not give it over till I know the cause of your melancholy fit, do you doubt my duty, or my loyalty? perhaps you do, and so make me the cause of your affliction.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: May such a thought within me, stick me to the endless torments.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It is lately entertained, what ever it be; you came heart whole to Town, and Jovial. Have you been drawn for security into Bonds by any of my friends, for great sums, and forced to pay them?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Fie, fie.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Are any great friends of yours in question, attainted, imprisoned, or run away?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Psewh.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Or are you further grieved about your Nephew, Careless? I thought that your friend Saveall, and myself had made his peace with you; and that you had sent for him, do you repent that?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: No, no, sweet heart, he shall be welcome. And pray let me entreat you make no further inquisition; If (as you suppose) there be a trouble in my thoughts, I shall soon pass it over.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Tell me, or I shall prove the greater trouble. I would those few examples of women, that could not keep their husbands counsels had been burnt, and the woman too rather than I should be distrusted thus, and slighted by a Husband

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Nay then you will grieve me indeed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
There has been many examples of discreet women
that have not only kept their husbands counsels, but advise and help them in extremities, and delivered them out of dangers.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I pray content yourself.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Be you content to tell me then what troubles you. And I pray you tell me speedily, now presently; or (excuse me in my vow,) it is the last request that ever I will make to you, and the last question I will ever ask you, and (the easier to get it from you) I promise you by the continuance of my faith to you (which by this kiss I seal) Be it a deadly injury to myself, I will forgive it freely; not be troubled at it.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I shall do that now, which few wise men would. But she is discreet, and has a fortitude Above the boast of women; should that fail, And this too weighty knowledge for a wife Should prove a torment to her, I am excused She pulls it on herself, and for Revenge Should she against her protestation move it, I am enough above her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You are resolved it seems to keep your secret Unto yourself, much good Sir may it do you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: No, you shall know it, sir, and (if unshaken Now, in your love to me) the wonder of all wives You are bound by a fair pledge, the kiss you gave me, To be unmoved, and to forgive it though It be a deadly injury to yourself; It is, and it is a great one; and so great But that you have sealed my pardon, the hid knowledge Of it should feed upon my Heart, and Liver, Till life were banished thence, rather than pull Your just revenge upon me; yet you frown not! But before I declare it to your Justice, Let me renew your mercy.

And on this Altar, which I have profaned
While it breathed sacred incense, now with penitence Offer religious vows, never to violate My Faith or Love to you again. One more
Before you hear it: for if then you stand not Firm to your Mercy, it must be my last.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What do you but violate your Love to me, Now in your most unjust suspicion?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I will trespass so no more; yet many husbands (I wish they had my sorrow, and no less Purposer to reformation) wrong their wives.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Leave these perambulations; to the point: You have unlawfully lain with some woman!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: It is said; and now your doom.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha. Here is a business! Would somebody heard you faith: nay of five hundred That now might overhear us (I mean not only Gallants, but grave substantial Gentlemen) Could be picked out a twelve good men and true, To find you guilty, I would then condemn you, But such a Jury must be panelled first.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: And can you be so mild? then farewell thought.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thought of your Mistress Sir, And then farewell My jealousy, for let me tell you Sir, That I have had an ache upon these brows Since your last being in Town. And since you have dealt So faithfully as to tell me it is one, (There is no more, is there?)

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: No upon my vow.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Name me the woman: if it be the same That I suspect, I will never suspect more.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: As faithfully as to my Confessor;
Saleware my Silkman's wife.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
The same I meant, You are a fair dealing husband. On what condition? Come this is merry talk. Prithee on what condition?
Only to bring good custom to her shop, And send her husband Venison (flesh for flesh) I did observe you bought all there last term, And wished me to her Shop, and Master. Saveall With divers others to bestow our monies. Troth she is a handsome one; Prithee on what conditions?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Thou shalt know all to purge me of my folly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well said.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: After a costly, and a tedious Suit With many an answer no, and no such Woman, At length she yields for a hundred pieces; Had them, and I enjoyed her once.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That was, When you last Term sat up all Night, and said you sat up with the three Lady Gamesters.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: It is confessed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fair dealing still.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: But here was the foul dealing, and for which I hate her now: I having paid so great a fine, and Ta'en possession thought after to deal Rent-free.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A Peppercorn a quarter, if she be Pepper proof.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: But she at my very next approach, which was but yesterday denies me Egress, except I make it a new purchase at the same former rate, and so for all times after.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Troth it is unreasonable, a hundred pound a time? How rich would Citizens be, if their wives were all so paid, and how poor the Court and Country! But hushed, here comes Master. Saveall with your Nephew, I take it; A handsome Gentleman, could he be so debauched?

sp.speaker: Sav.
Thr.
sp.p: Not a word of unkindness, Nephew, you are welcome, give me your hand, George, thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I shall be George of horseback once more I see. In all humility I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Nay now thou speakest, and lookest too tamely George, I would have thee keep and use the lively spirit that thou hadst, but not to let it fly at random, as it has done George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, I have learnt now by the inconveniences I have met with, in those extravagant out flights, the better to contain it within the limits of your leave, and fair allowance hereafter.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Well said, and again welcome George. But (and this you shall give me leave to say Master. Saveall) I remit your thanks for any inclination I had towards this reconcilement till I do you some further kindness; only you had good advocates, who pleaded friendly for you, Master. Saveall, and your Aunt there before she ever saw you whom you may thank.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A man must be so tied now.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Pray take notice of her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I cannot use respect enough Sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I like that modesty.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Doubt him in nothing, for he is come home.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Madam as you are my gracious Patroness, and myself so all unworthy, my duty checks me in my approach to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You are the more entirely welcome Cousin.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She Kisses like an old man's wife, That is, as a Child late starved at Nurse, sucks a fresh flowing Breast.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You must not Sir be bashful.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It will less become me to presume good Madam.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: George, here is a Lodging for you in this house, and my Table has a place for you, send for your man to wait upon you. Have you Wat still?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes Sir, an honest true hearted civil fellow he is, as I have managed him, he can say grace now.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: The world is well mended. tomorrow you shall give me a note of your debts George, which I will take order for, if I may presume you have any.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Some driblets Sir, My credit has not lately wronged me much.

sp.speaker: Sav.
Thr.
sp.p: Then not to wrong ourselves, let us in to Dance.

div2.stage: ACT II. SCENE I. Alicia, Lady, Servingman, Prentice.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: All Cheapside, and Lombard street Madam, could not have furnished you with a more complete bargain, you will find it in the wearing, and thank me both for the goodness of the stuff, and of the Manufacture.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
But now the price Mistress Saleware. I grant your Commodity is good, The Gold and Silver Laces, and the Fringes are rich, and I hope well wrought. Has your Man made a note of the particulars, and their prices, at
the rate of ready money (for I buy so) and not as you would book them to an under aged heir, or a court cavalier to expect payment two or three years hence; and find it perhaps never. I come with Here is one for the other.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I know your Ladyships payment such; And they are prized so Madam to a farthing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Let me see, broad plate Silver and Gold lace, two hundred and six Ounces half, and a dram, at five and ten pence the Ounce. sixty pound five shillings threepence ob. four five and ten pence an Ounce is dear.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I protest unto you Madam that parcel of Lace for a Bed as you intend it, was bespoken, and agreed for at six shillings the Ounce by a very great person: but because ready money came not to fetch it off, Fortune reserved it here for you, you could not have been so fitted on the sudden else within London walls; and I am glad the same fortune was so favourable to me, as by my hands to design it for your Ladyships use and pleasure. I hope Madam we shall hear of a young heir a coming shortly, and that will make it a rich and fortunate Bed indeed; And then Sir Oliver would thank me too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What a bold slut it is, well then the rest of the particulars here of Laees, and Fringes, Loops, and Buttons, makes the sum of all an hundred pound eight shillings four pence, halfpenny. I am no good Arithmetician, but if any be overcast, and overpaid, you must allow restitution.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes, good Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is all put up into this Box?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: All Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Give me my Purse. Take you home that while I make payment for it; your Gold weights Mistress Saleware.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Here Madam all in readiness.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You take no Gold but what is weight I presume.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: It is but light pains to weigh it Madam. But let me save your Ladyship that labour.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nor shall it be your trouble, command your Servant I pray for a glass of your beer

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Some beer for my Lady presently.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That I may tell you in more privacy, what perhaps you would not have him hear: for Prentices though they are bound to keep their Masters secrets, are not all privy to their Mistresses; that is more a Journeyman's Office.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Your Ladyship is pleased.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not very well with myself, for I have gone beyond my Commission in this bargain, and exceeded my Husbands allowance. Here is one hundred pounds eight shillings fourpence ob. in the Bill, and he allows me but the bare hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The odd money is but a small matter Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A great matter in an honest poor Country Ladies purse, may serve her a whole Christmas at Post and Pare, or Farthing gleek, when the gay Gamesters wives of the City may command the hundreds, out of the purses of such poor Ladies Husbands. But here is the odd money, eight shillings four pence, half penny, and so all is paid.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What means your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you not understand me then? I will tell you that which I thought fit to conceal from your servant; And from your husband too had he been here, perhaps he knows not on it. My husband left with you, or lent you the last Term a hundred pound, which he assigned to me; and now I have it in Commodity. Had you forgot it, when it was to do you a good turn, when your absent husband failed you, and you wanted it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: A good turn Madam?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes, was it not to have the free use of a hundred pound ready money, a whole quarter of a year, through a dead Vacation, and at last to take it out in wares? A good turn I think for a Tradeswoman; take heed you do not by your sullenness make me suspect another kind of good turn, or that you did my husband any to my injury, nor deny the receipt of his money, lest I take up a violence that will not become me, nor you be able to bear. Be therefore well advised both in what you say, and who hears me. Somebody comes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Madam your Beer.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will pledge you Mistress Saleware.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I shall presume then Madam

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: This was right cast, was it not friend?

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.p: Your Ladyship will find it so

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And I hope you will find your money so well bestowed Madam, that you will vouchsafe always to know the Shop.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ever upon the like occasion, Mistress Saleware, so most kindly farewell sweet Mistress Saleware.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The humblest of your servants Madam. Open the Boot for my Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It is done my Coach man does it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I would the Devil were in your Coachman's Coat to take his carriage for his pains.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: One word more Mistress Saleware, can it be he?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Lay your commands on me good Madam.

sp.speaker: La
sp.p: Not to your trouble, I perceive a young Gentleman attends for conference with you. Is not his name Fitzgerrard?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No Madam, his name is Bellamie, much depending on the young Lord Lovely.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I thought I had known him, he is a handsome youth. I cannot blame you now with him: but beware
of old Knights that have young Ladies of their own. Once more adieu sweet Mistress Saleware.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Most courteous Madam and once more to the Devil. But on my life her chaste Ladyship is taken with this beardless Bellamie. How she shot eyes at him!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now may your servant obtain a hearing Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: My ears are open Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But you are sad or angry, why seems that brow to threaten a subjection over him that is your vanquished captive; or has Cupid placed his Bow there bent at me, whose heart already lodges all his Arrows, never to be restored but by your pity?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Fie, fie upon it! what talk is this? I am vexed, and you would mad me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What has displeased you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: A cross business that has happened in my Shop today, I being none of the wisest Chapwoman, have undersold a parcel of the best Commodities my husband had. And should he know it we should have such a squabble.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Husbands should be so served that do impose Those mercenary Offices on their wives.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Talk so, and I will hear you, your amorous notes sound like Play speeches.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Servile, nay slavish Offices, ranking their wives with their prentices.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: They pretend only that we should overlook our servants, when they but set us there for show to draw in custom: but in making us such overseers they are overseen themselves; Shopkeepers wives will be meddling and dealing in their kind, and as they are able, as well as their husbands (some much better, and more profitable) but I was overreached I confess.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For no great matter I hope.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No, the matter was not much (that never fretted me) but the manner has even killed a She shop keeper. I cannot be long lived, here under a Penthouse, as my Lord (you know) told me when he said he would shut me out of this servitude, and that I should change my Coat, though my husband could not, before he were an Alderman, and be ranked with Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Lord has still the same regard of you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: So it appears by the Tailor and the Mercer, whom he sent four days since to measure me out, and suit me to his Honour, and no return of them found, yet his Land might have been measured all and sold, while a poor suit is dreamt on, had he born the mind of some Lord?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
I doubt not but this paper will clear that jealousy. And while you read I will speak that which I dare not utter through, Sighs and Blushes to an entire attention.
I am of Noble blood myself, free born, And not without good education; But since I am engaged in this employment, And made an instrument of others lust, I find myself a scandal to my Name, To Honour, and to Virtue, the base blot Of Pander sticking on me. But not this, Alone is my affliction. Here is my torment, That while I do true service to my Lord (Whom I must ever honour) in my Agency Unto yourself (whom I cannot but love) I find myself a Traitor to his trust, In my negotiation for myself. Nor can I find it possible to desist, Mine own attempts, to you, or forbear to urge Your constancy to him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How easy a work It were for one woman to supply them both, And hold her husband play to level Acoile, A wooden two leaved book, a pair of Tables Would do it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How wretched is that suppliant, who must make Suit to obtain that, which he fears to take!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: At the bear at the Bridge-foot six a clock, good. Sir, I find my Lords honourable appointments here, and have heard you all this while.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now I could wish, and was in hope you had not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I will not blame you on your Lords behalf; Because you have enough rebuked yourself. But Sir, if you presume upon the favour I give your Lord, and therefore to obtain me, Cause I am his, you undervalue me To think that I can stoop unto his servant, Though almost his Companion, you may think After that degradation by degrees, I may, in time, descend unto his Footman, I am no cast Garment of his Lordships yet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You have schooled me fairly, I am humbled, Lady

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Dee hear, dee hear sir, Master. Bellamine, One word before you go.

sp.speaker: Pren.
sp.p: What would he buy Mistress? can you take his money? Sir dee hear?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray attend you the the other end of the Shop, If I cannot handle a Customer, why does your Master trust me? Could a frown fright you? Let a smile then cheer you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And that is a heavenly one, As that of Cynthia at Endymion.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray leave your Player-like passionate expressions. And if you love me, like a Man speak to me. As I am a Woman; are you silent? if you doubt the length of my man's Ears at that distance, you may whisper what so? But that is a right shop whisper indeed with Tradeswomen that are handsome; Is that the most you will give sir? Could I afford it so, do you think I would make two words with ye? yet this before you go
Now match it for the price I will give it you for nothing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I shall forget I have a Lord. I must forget him here.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Do so, and if (I say) you love me, speak plainly what you would have me do, or what you would do with me (I love to daunt these young things that love before they can love to the purpose, or speak to it handsomely like a Boy that would fain be shooting at wildfowl, before he knows how to discharge a Birding piece) I would hear you speak, you have often muttered and fribbled some intentions towards me, but I would hear you speak. Come, if you love me lay by the fear of the Lord that sent you, and tell me roundly now, what you would have me do?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I would entreat you

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well; what?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That you would be pleased

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: With what? or to do what?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: To wear this pair of Silk stockings for me?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Is that all your suit, it is granted, with my thanks to you; Have you no more to say?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, I say you are the beautifulest of Women; and that my Lord in your enjoyment is the happiest

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Nay think not of your Lord, but ask me, something.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I would but dare not hope for such a favour, you will never grant it, my unworthiness.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How can you tell?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You will not wrong my Lord, so as to do it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Not in his sight perhaps. What is it? come.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It is

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: It is then, let it be so. Go to School child.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It is That you would, let me give you this ring, And grace it with your Finger.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Will that be a wrong to your Lord?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, to wear any favours, but his own.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Does he know this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, nor I would not that he should (and given by me) for all the Rubies in Cheapside, where I bought this but now, over the way.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Come sir, I will daily with ye no longer, I know what you would have with me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And now you will betray me: I am shamed then and undone.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No, but I have you of the hip. It is plain you would lie with me: deny it if you can.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O dear, did I say so now?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What need you when I know it, you would lie with me, and you shall. Take courage man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But, in good earnest, shall I? shall I?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes, in good earnest, you will find it no trifling business, when you come to it once. But sir, upon condition.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Any condition Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: All purpose on it is lost, and all comes out else.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Name your condition, I will perform it if it be in the power of my life.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You saw here at your coming a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I took no notice of her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But she did of you, she is called the Lady Thrivewell.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Sir Oliver Thrivewells Lady?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The same, you have known her it seems.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Seen her before she was married.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I will be brief with you, as you love me she loves you as eagerly, but with much more boldness, you saw her whisper me, and how loath she was to depart, when her eye was upon you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I did observe it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: She is my noble friend, and the sweetest Lady, I need not set her out. But though you think you suffer in your honour, in being an instrument betwixt your Lord and me, with the base blot of Pander sticking on you, (these were your words) I have engaged myself for her to be your Panderess; be so, I shall be even with you in business if you account it so.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What dee mean Lady?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To urge against myself, for that sweet Lady, which no Woman else I think would do, that loves you so unfeignedly as I. But it is my fate, and the injunction I must lay upon you, to make me yours. That first you give yourself to her Embraces; I will give you means for your access to her, and your success with her, which done, and on your faith affirmed to me, it is so, I will perpetually be yours more freely than your Lords.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You urge this but to try my constancy.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: For that I will satisfy you soon, my husband coming we must tonight at the Bear My Lord writes so.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p:
And there I will direct you in your progress. Ally how dost? Master. Bellamy how is it? How does my noble Lord? You are sad methinks. Have you overbought anything here, and so repent your bargain? Or cannot my wife, and you agree upon it? you must use Master. Bellamy
kindly my sweet Ally: he is our noblest Lords most special favourite, and must find all fair dealing here, as well when I am abroad as at home sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You hear not me complain sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: What an assinego is this! He might have thanked me for my good words, though I meant him no good will, I hope thou hast overreached him indeed.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Thomas your hopes are vain, Thomas in seating me here to overreach, or underreach anybody. I am weary of this Mechanic course Thomas; and of this courser habit, as I have told you divers and sundry times Thomas, and indeed of you Thomas that confine me to it, but the bound must obey.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word, I hope sweet Ally; Not of me nor of my shop I prithee at seasonable times Love. But for thy habit (though this be decent on a Citizens wife) use thine own fancy, let it be as Courtly, or as Lady-like as thou pleasest, or my Lords desires.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Then I am friends again.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Troth, and I will call thee friend, and I prithee, let that be our familiar and common compilation: friend it will sound daintily, especially when thou shalt appear too gallant to be my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Then let it be so friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: In truth it shall, and I am very much taken with it. Friend I have found a Customer today that will take off my rich parcel of broad Bed lace, that my Lord Paylate bespoke, and left on my hands, for lack of money.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I have sold it already friend, with other Laces at a good rate.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And all for ready money friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes friend, a hundred pounds, and somewhat more.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Who would be, or who could live without such a friend, in such a shop? This money comes so pat for a present occasion, to stop a gap. It has stopped a gap already friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I have disposed of the money, the odd hundred pound for apparel, friend, and other accommodations for myself.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word I hope friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I have done it friend, whereby to appear more Courtly, and Ladylike as you say, to gain you more custom to your Shop.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Ouch friend Is it so?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And friend you must not be angry, or think much of it, if you respect your profit friend.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I were no friend but a wretch if I would. No let it go friend, and Sapientia mea mihi is my word, I must not grudge at my friend in anything.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Then friend, let your shop be your own care for the rest of this day, I have some business abroad.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Whither sweet friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Is that a friendly question?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I am corrected friend, but will you not take a Man to wait upon you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To watch me, shall I? and give you account of my actions? was that spoke like a friend?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I am again corrected friend, Do your own pleasure, you will return to supper.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yet again?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And again, I am corrected friend:

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Neither to supper, nor to bed perhaps.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word I hope.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But if I chance to stay, you cannot be a faithful friend and ask me where, or in what company, friendship you know allows all liberty.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p:
Sapientia mea mihi. A witty wife, with an imperious will,
Being crossed, finds means to cross her Husband still; And Tradesmen that so match, must not with Gall Temper their wives, but sweetly by wit all.

div2.stage: Exit. Enter Carelesse, with two Letters in his hand, and Wat with a Candle, and Wax.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Does not the World come finely on, Wat, ha? And have not we convenient comings in already, ha!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Better than we know how to have paid, for that is the glory on it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I need no more ensconcing now in Ram alley, nor the Sanctuary of Whitefriars, the Forts of Fullers rents, and Milford lane, whose walls are daily battered with the curses of bawling creditors. My debts are paid; and here is a stock remaining of Gold, pure Gold hark how sweetly it chinks.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, and it will ring the changes shortly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: For necessaries Wat, for necessaries it shall change, and Ring all out, and it will so long as I have an Uncle, and know to manage him, let money fly, I can no faster spend than he supply.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: For necessaries sir, but you must not now count Sack and Tobacco, Whores and Fiddlers in abundance, necessaries.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why pray?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Because you will have but little then for extraordinaries, That is to say in a Gentleman for charitable, and pious works and uses.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The fellow is spoiled.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
Not spoiled neither: For I would but wave your purpose of flying at all new Game, and neglect your poor whore, who now begins to be so violent for
wrongs, she can no longer bear, that she intends to pursue you with her complaints hither to your Uncles House.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: My Uncles house? my house. Is not the first Mornings draught mine?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: With great reason, for you are first dry in the morning.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is not the question first asked me, what will you have to breakfast? what will please you for Dinner, and what for Supper? Has not my Uncle let out monies, and taken Bonds and Mortgages in my name? do not his Tenants crouch to me, and his servants all call me young Master? And does not my Uncle take care to marry me to ten thousand pound, and a thing like a wife?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You have got a brave possession here, I must needs say; and I applaud your fortune most in this, that your young Aunt the noble Lady here, who you see feared would prove a cruel Stepdame to you, appear to be more friend to you than your Uncle. It is a more gracious Sunshine in her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She shall lose nothing by it. I have thought: a way to requite her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: But sir, for Mistress Phebe, will you take no order for the poor soul?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I do not like your zealous solicitation, but here is an order for her, in answer of her Malapert Letter you brought me last night. Give it her, and these five pieces upon condition that she never come, write, or send to me again, till I send to her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: That is somewhat hard Sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay look you Wat, you are a little mistaken in me. I must give over whoring, for special causes there unto me moving.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
O now I find you. And it were richly worth
your patience, if you could win the Widow by it, for whom you stood in fair election once, until your last debauchment.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I shall stand fairer for her sir, when I leave working but a week or two, shall I not?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, if you leave it quite, but to forsake her whom you have brought low, to fall to others, were such a thing

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well sir, it may be I will, it may be I will not, what is that to you? carry you the Letter, and the Money, and try how that will work with her.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I will do my best, but if she should exclaim, and bring on her Cousin Master. Saleware to be clamorous

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Her Cousin is a Cuckold, exclaim and clamorous! give me my money again.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Nay I am gone sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The Rogue is in faction with them; O noble Master. Saveall, you have most fairly kept your minute with me, I have written my Letter, sealed it and all, here to the Widow.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: So early? that is well.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have written no less than six large Epistles this morning, and sent them now by my Man to be conveyed into the Country to Lords and Knights, with all the news spiritual, and temporal, foreign and domestic that could possibly fall into a private Gentleman's Collection.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: With such dexterity, that if I would make a Trade on it, I could undo all the Newsmongers in Town that live by it.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p:
It is a most commendable practise in a Gentleman, and it will mature your judgment in the both
Commonwealth and State affairs, and in short time invite you unto the chair of Helm.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: When I am once married, and settled, you shall see what an ass it is, he believes me.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: How am I comforted in my Meditation for you, and how overjoyed will your Uncle be at the use you make of your retirements!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I confess it is (by reason of my unwontedness to it) some difficulty for me to write to women; wherefore since you have so nobly undertaken the conveyance of this, let me beseech you to apologize for the rudeness of my style.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: To the fair hands of the most accomplished in virtue Mistress Anne Crostill, present, I pray with my service; The outside hath no rudeness on it, and (I doubt it not) she shall find within all sweetness and urbanity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As you may interpret it to her sir.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Sir, what I have already said, and do intend to say unto her from your Uncle, and myself on your behalf, together with what you have here written, shall (I doubt it not) prepare so fair a way of proceeding for you; That at your visit of her you may say, veni, vidi, vici, she is your own.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And then a ha, Master. Saveall!

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Expect your fortune modestly, and when it comes embrace it with discretion.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, I am edified.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: It is well if you be so; I will put my undertaking in action presently, Pray for my good success.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
I dare not tell him now I cannot; but I wish well for the Monies sake; and let the Vintners pray, and all the decayed Sparks about the Town, whom I will raise out of ashes into flame again. Let them pray for my good works. O my young Lady aunts grave waiting
Woman. If she were not hers, and out of this house I should take her for a Bawd now. But being hers, and here how much may I mistake? all flesh is frail.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Not to disturb your morning Meditations, my Lady has sent you

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And you have brought me, what sweet Mistress Closet?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: A part of her Ladyships own breakfast, it is very cordial and comfortable to the spirits, I assure you, and delectable to the younger sort, and profitable to the old.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: One of Robert Greens works, or the mad Doctor that preaches boiled in it I think.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: It is a composition of mine own Sir, of many excellent decoctions, of most wholesome restorative, and costly ingredients.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That it was sent by her makes it more excellent, whose bounteous care of me, I must acknowledge exceeds all cost in carving to me, and countenancing me at her Table, in gracing me in presence of the Ladies that come to visit her; in giving charge for decency in all things for my Chamber, my fires shining, my odours burning, my livery served in, my soft and costly bed prepared and spread with perfumed linen here is ambergris in this now

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O is it so, do you find that?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But though she is my own Uncles wife, I could even say it is pity a young man had her not.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: What a wag is this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She is a most sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
She is a sweet Lady indeed, I can best speak
it that have known her from the womb hitherto: A sweet infant she was born, and a sweet babe I swaddled it, and a sweet child I nursed it, I trained it up a sweet child. It was in manners a sweet child, at her Book and Sample a sweet child. I never whipped it but once, and then it was sweet too, and sprawled but a little, and whimpered but a little it was so sweet a child; And so she grew upwards, and upwards towards woman, and a sweet youngling she was, and so grew upwards and upwards towards man, and then a sweet Bride she was, and now a most sweet Lady she is, (as you say, and I commend you for it) And so she stands at a stay. For now she grows no more upwards than upon her Wedding day, not upwards as I would have her upwards, here I mean young Gentlemen, could I but see a sweet babe of hers once by my Master, I could be then content to sleep with my Ancestors.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I had rather see your Gibship hanged up with Polecats in a Warren, and your sweet Lady with you, though I confess that were some pity. I hope her barrenness, or his will preserve her from my curse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I hope still, and she hopes still; and I make him of this broth for every morning, and many other good strengthening things (I cannot say for the same purpose) for I shall never see him have an heir by her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Excellent! that is best of all.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Because you then are heir, say you so? Is that your love to your Aunt?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No I protest Nurse, I meant by the broth, the bottom was the best of all.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Then I cry mercy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cannot all thy art, and her cost find help for my Uncle, thinkst thou, to get a child?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p:
Help! what dee mean. He might have help
and helps enough, were she not too virtuous.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Still thou mistakest me Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Away wag away, your Aunt loves you too well to think so of her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nurse as I hope to inherit anything hereafter

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I should but serve you well to tell her your good thought of her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nurse, by this good peace I think no harm.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Nay, nay.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Take it I say. And tell her if thou wilt, that I love her so well, that were she not mine Uncles wife, I would get her an heir myself rather than be his.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Kind young Master, now I am heartily sorry that I moved you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And for my Uncle were I his heir apparent, I rather wish he might live till all this World were weary of him, and the next afraid to take him, Than I survive him (Tongue, a pox punish you for lying) Now I live well, and merrily good Nurse, Wealth and Estates, bring cares and troubles with them, Were all young heirs of my contented mind, Parents and Patrons would be better prayed for.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Good Gentleman. Nurse Closet.
Closet

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O my Lady calls.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Present my thanks and best respects unto her.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I should have told you first I have forgot. My head is naught,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What member hast thou good then?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: My Lady desires you This talk has put me out O this head! My Lady desires you

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Desires she me Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Yes sir, she desires you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Refuse me if I desire not her as much, for all she is my Uncles leavings.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: My Lady desires you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And she shall have me Nurse If she were ten Uncles wives, and she ten of mine Aunts.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: O this head! nay now you will not hear me, she desires you to go abroad in the Coach with her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Any whither, to Islington, Newington, Paddington, Kensington, or any of the City out leaps (I know them all) for a spirit and back again, tell her I am up and ready for her, and could have been without her stirrup porridge, though I thank her for her care. A man cannot be too well prepared, or provided for so sweet a Lady, in so much distress. A very Andromeda, chained to a Rock.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: What is this you say? I understand no word of it, I would take your answer right, though I faltered in my Ladies message.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The Devils in this overrunning Tongue of mine, I could find in my heart to worm him out with my teeth.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: What must I tell my Lady Sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That I am more obliged to her Ladyship than I was to my Mother, she has brought me a new man into the World, and that my Being and my Life is hers.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I hope he is a true convertite, did I send you to hold discourse here, Closet?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Nor did I Madam but I could hear this Gentleman a whole day methinks. He speaks so acknowledgingly of your Ladyships virtue, and goodness towards him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am beholding to him, will you go with me Nephew to the Exchange? I am to buy some toys there for the Country, you may get a fancy by it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Good, I must wear her favours.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Or cannot you forbear your study so long?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To do you service Madam, under whose commands I build my happiness.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Be not at the distance of complement with me good Nephew.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I would not be thought insolent dear Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Come the Coachman grumbles at my stay, and it will be Dinner time presently, so the Cook will be angry too.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are all tenderness to your servants Madam.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: A sweet Gentleman, and bountiful, if my Lady had been blessed with such a Husband, what a place had I had!

div2.stage: ACT III. SCENE I. Enter Crostill reading a Letter, Saveall.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Do you know the contents Master. Saveall of the familiar Epistle you have brought me here?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: No Lady, but I guess it a fair expression of the Writers affection to you, although he desired me to crave your pardon for the rudeness of his style, it being the first that he hath composed of that consequence.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I will trust you sir, with the full knowledge of it, pray read it yourself.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I find she is pleased, and my endeavour prosperous, for the young Gentleman, I am sorry that I delayed a day in the delivering of it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Pray read it out sir, for I find it so pleasant that I could hear it a whole day together.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: In the first place you shall give me leave to wonder at your impudence (though it be but in your dreams) to have a thought that I ever intended, or can be drawn by persuasion, force, or the power of witchcraft to marry you Bless me! sure if he writ this, the Devil dictated to him.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: On sir, that is but his first charge.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Secondly, I am to tell you, that I am warm in mine Uncles favour. And it is not a piece a time, or five pieces for a piece of pleasure can undo me; and so I can have change, and scape the captivity of Wedlock. This could no otherwise be done but by the Devil that ought him the shame.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What follows I pray, there is the first and second point past? mark his method.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Thirdly, and lastly, let me advise you, since you are so hot upon Marriage, though I assure myself you love none but me, (and I thank you for it) that you frame or dissemble an affection to someone of the City, who is but comparative to yourself in blood and fortune, and so you may make by-use of me as your friend, and have children like me, George Careless.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Have you ever heard so quaint a Love Letter?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Lady, the injury done in it, to yourself is unanswerable, but my wrong in being his Messenger, I will make him answer.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Excuse me Sir, he has done me a favour; I pray inform him so with my great thanks. But for what you conceive a wrong to yourself, use your discretion, you have no more to say to me for him at this present, have you sir?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Not for him but against him, I will unsay all that I said before intended for his good.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But I will not hear you wrong your former love, and judgment of him so, which made so deep impression here, that I had locked his love up as a Jewel in my Breast, and you in striving now to wrest it thence may break the Cabinet; I rather wish you will be a friendly means to draw his presence hither, that I myself may mildly question him.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Are you serious Lady?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I fear I shall not rest before I see him, but do not tell him that, lest in this sullen humour, he force his absence to afflict me more; I will hold you sir no longer, deal for me as you can, I know you have a guess at my desire.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I will do you service in it.

I guess that her desire is to do some act of Revenge upon him. And (so it be not mortal) it were but Justice in her for so gross a scorn by him cast upon a well reputed Gentleman. Yet is it observed in her that she has a violent humour to do, and not to do things oftentimes wilfully against all good council or persuasion, she has the spirit of contradiction in her, and an unalterable resolution upon sudden intentions, a most incorrigible will she has that will not bow nor break. This cross abusive Letter therefore may do good upon her,
however mischievous he might intend it. If she meant well to him before, it may the faster bring her on, but it amazes me that he should write so, bearing his Uncle, and myself in hand, that he so fairly loved her, and besought us to negotiate with her for him, should she forgive it, yet the wrong to us in his vile manners is unpardonable, and so sir, I come to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O Master. Saveall

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: What mischief or despite have I ever done you, That could provoke your desperate spleen against me, To wound mine honour?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What do you mean good sir?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: You have employed me basely, made me your Carrier of scandal, and scurrility to the hands Of nobleness and virtue. Could the Fiend Lust that is in you suffer you to write No other Sense or Language to a person Of her fair Name, and Worth, than such as Ruffians Would send to strumpets? or it being such.
Could not a Porter, or your Pander there Serve for the lewd conveyance? What a welcome is that!

sp.speaker: Sav.
Car.
sp.p:
Hold I beseech you, and sir, though I lose the Widow by my error (which was indeed but a mere accident) let me not be so miserable made as to lose you, before you hear a short Examination
Delivered you the Letter which I sent Yesterday to the Damsel that you wot of?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p:
Yes sir, she read it, kissed it a hundred times, Then made a bosom Idol on it, And says you are the noblest Gentleman
Under a Saint that ever took care for sinner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hell take her for a mistaking whore, She has the widows Letter, and the widow hers, I found it sir, when you judiciously Said it was Ruffian-like, and Strumpet language.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How could you err so strangely?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O slightly, slightly, curse of my heedless brain! And then too be trapped with carelessness. When I was so religiously resolved, To incline to virtue, and a Marriage life, Thinking with one hand to cast off my follies, And to take hold of virtue with the other, For sir, (I will confess myself to you) The Letter you conveyed was in defiance, A loose lived wanton, intended to a whore, That impudently hopes an interest in me.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: It was not so directed.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I there was (The Hell confound it on it) my giddiness: I sealed both Letters ever I superscribed them, And so gave each the contrary direction.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: It was a gross carelessness, and if you lose A fortune by it, do not blame your friends.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That fortune should favour a whore before An honest woman. It was the sweetest Letter, The daintiest winning things (the Devils in it) She must not carry it from the widow so. Fetch me the Letter again.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Do you think she will part with it sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cannot you beat it out of her sir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I cannot tell how to do that.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thus sir I will give you demonstration, you malicious Rogue, you that conspirest with her to betray me, so good a Master I have been to thee, and so good a friend to her, I will recompense you both.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You have undone us both, and will discard us now you are warm in your Uncles bosom again but

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But what you Traitor you?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You put me in good mind, and if I do not somewhat.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I owe you somewhat for your last nights absence, too pernicious Villain that keepest thyself out of the way on purpose that I should be drunk, and abuse myself, and the house here all lay of your absence, There is somewhat more for that.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: It is all upon account sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Who knows an honest Serving-man that wants a good Master.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Was it your man's fault Master. Careless? if I be not revenged etcetera

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No faith, To speak truth he was as much abused in it, as you in doing a thing as contrary to his vile conditions, as you did to your noble Name. But I crave only your pardon, I know not what I do besides. This cross blow of chance staggers my reason so

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Well sir, since I have found the error, my reason reconciles me to you, and since it grew out of your equal intent to cast off the evil, as to embrace the good, I will remediate for you to the widow.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But yet she will know I have had a whore. Yet then you may say, it is such a running Disease among young Gentlemen, that not one of a hundred has scaped it, that have proved stayed men afterwards, and very sober husbands; As look you yonder one may prove, whom now I have in good sooth a great desire to beat.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In your Aunts presence, and your Uncles house; Though I were not his friend; could you be so outrageous? I muse I see him here though.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cry you mercy sir, are you his friend?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I make myself so, he being dependent to my noblest Lord, whom I am bound to honour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What Lord I pray, that I may honour him too.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The Lord Lovely.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That loves women above wine, wine above wealth, wealth above friend, and friends above himself. There is no scandal in all that sir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: It goes so of him indeed, but he loves honour above all those.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Master. Saveall a word.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Your servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In the name of flesh, for what does his Lordship employ that Angleworm to my Aunt? He has had her this hour in private conference, close chambered up together, not so much as Matron Nurse in the room with them, It is a fine sleek thing, and almost pity to hunt it, but sure I must beat it, as place and time convenient may serve.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray Master. Saveall move you my Husband for it, I would not meddle in his money matters willingly.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Five hundred pound for my Lord upon the mentioned security, I will break it to sir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is that the business after so much privacy? very pretty, my Aunts a woman too, and my Uncle may have as forked a fortune, as any of the City, that lend out money to hedge in Lordships.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am his Lordships servant.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And I your Lordships good Madam. And yours Master. Saveall.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I am for your way Master. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And I sir, if it please you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: George Careless, I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: May I not wait upon your Gentleman to the Gate Madam?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No good George, though I commend your courtesy, yet would I not you should neglect your own dignity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Um I am under Government.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: The young man, if you have modesty will think you mock him, if not you will make him become arrogant, know you not whose man he is?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No it is apparent, this over slighting of him proclaims she loves him, whose follower Madam, and I know Lords followers, Knights fellows.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not all Lords followers to all Knights George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To as many as their fair Ladies will give way to, that are not faint-hearted.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I understand you not George; something troubles you, you are not right today.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am only as I am in your favour Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Come I know what perplexes you, and it is therefore that I desire to talk with you; I am not angry with you, but let me tell you George, although not openly I took notice of the pickle you came home in last night, after your Uncle was in Bed; to whom, marvelling at your absence I excused you, as gone at my request to visit some Ladies with whom you staid Supper, I told him, when you were with your Rousers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But did you never go?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Indeed I did, and he was satisfied.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O my sweet Lady Aunt! I was indeed amongst them, and deeply merry.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And drunk as deeply!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will abuse your goodness so no more.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say and hold George, for your own good.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What is now become of me, I am under correction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I would you could have seen yourself, and how your disguise became you, as I was told, I do but friendly tell you of some passages, as they were to me related, by those whom I have charmed to speak no more on it. Be secure therefore in your Uncle:

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O my dear heavenly Aunt!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: First, at the door you bounced like a Giant at the Gate of an enchanted Castle, before which could be opened offence was taken by you at your Sedan-men; for asking money (as appeared afterwards) more than you brought from the Tavern, and leaving their office fouler by a distempered stomach full, than you found it. In the strife for these sad causes your Sword being seized on, you being unable to use it, were found by my servants at Lugs with your brace of Corps bearers, in the dirt, and their poor hovel Chair turned on his ridge in the Kennel.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will never be drunk again.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I hope you will say so, when you have heard all George; but by the way your late stock being spent, here are ten pieces towards a supply.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O sweet golden Aunt!

Well sir, the strife appeased, you were ta'en in. Then hey is there no Sack in the house? It is for you in you Chamber is replied, up you are had, where is the Rogue my man? not seen since Yesterday; Fetch me a wench. Bless us cries old Sim the Butler, we have none in the house, nor cannot send for any out of doors.
