Dost tell me that? is not my Ladies Woman, my Ladies Chambermaid, the Laundry maid, the wench under the Cook, my Ladies Nurse old Winter plum, nor my Lady herself within? I know, or will know all the she things in the house.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But why me up in your bedroll George?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sigh.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You remember none of this!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It is not worth it Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nor how you scared Chambermaid, whom I sent in love to see care taken for you, not dreaming of any ill thought in you, do you remember how you told her, and what you would give her, when your Uncle died for a small present courtesy? she was fain to satisfy you with a false promise to steal to bed to you before four men could force, or humour you into it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What an unhallowed Rascal was I!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It is well you consider it now. And still consider George. How ill excess of Wine, Roaring and Whoring becomes a Gentleman, and how well sobriety, courtesy, and noble action, and dangers wait upon the one sort, and what safety accompanies the other!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Wine, Roaring and Whoring, I will lay that saying of yours Madam to my heart; but Wine is the great wheel that sets the rest a whirling.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: True George, for had you not first been sullied with Wine, you would not have abused yourself to have tumbled in the dirt with your Litter mules, nor offered to seduce my Chambermaid. Suppose you had overcome her, how could you have come off but with shame to yourself, and the utter ruin of the poor Wench?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Still she corrects me for my meddling with base matters and people, she is not angry she says, though I called for her last night in my drink, she gives me money, I will now understand her, and whereunto all her former favours and her later admonitions are directed, and presently appear a grateful Nephew.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, be not sad upon it George, as I would win you from your faults, I would have you still be cheerful. If any thought troubles you, you may be free with me George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O Madam you have made me, and now take me to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How mean you?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Freely and wholly, the truest, faithfullest servant, and I think the ablest that any Lady of your lacks and longings ever bestowed a favour on, though I say it myself. You will swear it when you have tried me, if it be but hourly for a month together.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is the man sound trow?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I defy Surgeon, or the Apothecary can come against me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sound in your senses sir, I mean.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O for blabbing Madam never fear me, now I am resolved to live soberly, and be only yours. And with such pleasure, with such safety, secrecy, and fulness, I will so constantly supply you, that you shall not have time to dream of the defects of your old man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you mean your Uncle, and not know whose wrong you unnaturally and sinfully pursue?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No man living Madam can do it for him, more naturally and less sinfully; I am of the same flesh and blood, and bring his youth to your pleasure, how can you think old Uncles children are got? or how came up the proverb, She is one of mine Aunts, do you think? You would have a child by him. All your Caudles and Cock broths will never do it, An old man's generative spirit runs all into brain, and that runs after covetousness too, get wealth, not children. Believe it, much Nephews help belongs to it, and then the children are not degenerate, I cannot think but many Uncles know it, and give way to it, because stranger bloods shall not inherit their Lands, and so sweet Aunt if I live not to inherit his, my son may, in your first born. There will be a sweet comfort to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But is all this in earnest?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In earnest? yes, And I pray so take it, and let it be a bargain, and now presently in the Chamber, I will make you my first payment for the purchase.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fie, fie, you do but say so?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That shall be tried presently. Come sweet Madam, I find you are willing, and I swear I am resolute, and will be as secret as your own woman, if you will not go I protest I will carry you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay prithee George set me down a little.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Psewgh I need none of these wheezings I.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But prithee tell me, dost thou not all this only to try me, or am I a Rogue think you, or wouldst thou seriously that thine own natural Uncle, thy bountiful Patron, nay thy father on the matter, should suffer such a wrong, and done by us?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hark there again, Madam have I not proved sufficiently and plainly, that I shall in doing the feat for him do him the greatest right in the world, in getting him, and you an indubitable heir, and to give him both the comfort, and the glory of it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Was ever such a Reprobate?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And you can do him no wrong (though you had not a Ladies privilege) to Cuckold him, for assure yourself he Cuckqueans you, now come Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You speak not on your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I never was his Pimp, but what I have heard, I have heard. Now come Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I heard Master. Saveall protest within these three days that he thought my Husband the chastest man (of a Gentleman) that he knows.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O did he so, Madam, believe it they two have whored together, and that Saveall has pimped for him oftener than you ever lay with my Uncle.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What! since he married me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What else? Saveall is not only his grave Parasite, but his Pimp, and has spent my Uncle more in these civil punctual ways, than I in all my whole debauches, what did you think he kept him for? O they are a brace of subtle dry Tweaks, come now Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What an inhumane villain is this!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will tell you all now upon our inward acquaintance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You have told too much already to have any acquaintance with me at all, nor shall you, unless you presently recant all that you have, or would have said upon this subject.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Madam

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Stand further and reply not, less I call in those that shall sadly silence you. Have you abused your Uncle, and the next best friend you have in the World, in hope thereby to abuse me most, that was no enemy of yours till now you justly have provoked me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I took not a right course.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Was this the best construction you could make of my love to you, or a fit requital, to make me an incestuous Whore?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, yes, a pox my course was right enough, but I undertook her at an ill season. Her spruce springals left her but now, I will tell her so Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Come I perceive you are sorry; and that is a part of satisfaction. Therefore for once I will wink at your transgression, especially before others. Here is one you see.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I do, the Devil blind her.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Madam

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But tempt me so again, and I will undo you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I know how you will undo me witty Madam, Ah

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay be not sad George, discover not yourself, and you are safe, for once I tell you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She will come about I see.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But will you Cozen go, and do that for me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Most readily good Madam, I have your full directions.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: All Cousin, if you forget not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I cannot be so negligent in your service Madam, I find by this feigned errand she dares not trust her trollop there, I love her wit now too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He is both schooled, and cooled I hope. Now Closet what is your News?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Of a Citizen Madam that entreats to speak with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you not know his Name, or Trade?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes, I had both even now, but I have such a Head.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: If you have lost them by the way pray go back and seek them, or bring you his business.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I asked his business Madam, and told him he might trust me with it without a hand to his book, but he said it could not be delivered, but by his own word of mouth to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What strange matter is it trow? or what Citizen, is not his Name Saleware?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and he is a (O this head) a

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A Silkman is he not?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes Madam the same.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I hope his impudent Wife has not told him all; if she has, where is his remedy in this Woman's Law case?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: There is a Gentleman with him too Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Then we shall have it, It is his Wife sure, well I
am prepared for the encounter. Bid them come up, if they grow violent or too bold with me, I will set my Nephew George upon them. It is not his Wife, what Creature is it trow with me, Master. Saleware?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Craving your pardon Madam, a few words in the behalf of this poor Kinswoman of mine, touching a Gentleman, who I hear lives in your House, Master. George Careless, Madam, by whom she has received much injury.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How sir I pray?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Pray Madam read this Letter, weep not, but hold up thy head Cuz, we will not be dashed, nor bashed in a good cause; pray read you Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am now (Lady) in favour with my Uncle, and in fair possibility of a good Estate, deporting myself (I intend to do) a civil Gentleman. To which end (induced as well by reason, as by long continued affections) I tender myself to you in the holy condition of Marriage. If you vouchsafe your consent, (which is my most earnest request) I shall not only declare myself a good Husband, but the most happy, Geo. Careless.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Wherein appears the injury to your Kinswoman?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: In flying from his Word, and Deed Madam. He has born her in hand these two years, and use her at his pleasure, detaining her from her choice of many good fortunes, and at last sends her this to make amends for all, and denies his act the next day, sending his man to take the Letter from her, pretending it was directed to another. But never the sooner for a hasty word Cousin, we will not be dashed nor bashed, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Here is the direction. To the Lily white Hands of Mistress Mariana Gymcrack, is that your Name Lady?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I am the sorrowful one that is known by it Madam.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word Cousin.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I conceive the business, and find the error, and my great doubt is over.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Weep not I say.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What would you have me do Master. Saleware?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: You have discretion Madam, and I made choice of your Ladyship to open this matter unto you, rather than to Sir Oliver himself, whom I would not willingly exasperate against his Nephew, you may be pleased in a milder way to temper him, and work a satisfaction for my Kinswoman; Sir Oliver and yourself Madam, are noble Customers to my Shop, and for your sakes I would not deal rigorously with your Kinsman, if a gentle end may be made. But, if you cannot so compound it, the Law lies open, money and friends are to be found, a good cause shall not be starved, I will not be dashed nor bashed, Sapientia mea mihi is my word, and so good Madam you know my mind.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It is pity a Gentlewoman should suffer too much, and I like her so well at first sight, that I am easily moved to do good for her, is she your Kinswoman in blood Master. Saleware, or your wife's?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Mine I assure your Ladyship, though my wife can boast as great and noble friends I thank fortune, as the wife of any Tradesman that carries a head in the City, (but that is by the by) yet I came of a better house, and am a Gentleman born, none dispraised.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well Master. Saleware, leave your Kinswoman with me a little while, you shall not be seen in my act, I will try what I can do for her.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: With all my heart good Madam, and dee hear Marina, This is a noble Lady, bear yourself discreetly in the business, and towards her: you may get a Husband by it, or at least a composition that may purchase one to shoulder you up. But carry it high and worthy of the house I brag of, or Sapientia mea mihi, stultitia tua tibi, That is my sentence.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Well sir, you need not doubt my high Carriage.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Closet.
Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Take this Gentlewoman to your Chamber, and I charge you let none see her, or take notice of her, but yourself and me, till I give order.
I shall do something for her doubt not Master Saleware.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I shall be bound to your Ladyship, now to my Shop, to which I thank my Wife she has been a Wildcat these two days, which must be born with as we are friends. And from my House all Night, and yet no Green goose fair time; Nor though she were so absent must I be so unfriendly as to question her, where, or with whom she was; a new Article this betwixt Man and Wife! But Sapientia mea mihi, stultitia sua sibi. Thus it must be where Man and Wife are friends, and will continue so in spite of chance, or high heeled shoes, that will awry sometimes with any Women. She is not yet come home hear. What Ladies that, and not my Wife there to handle her handsomely for her Money? My servants are such Assinegoes! stay, are mine

eyes perfect? It is she, it is my Friend wife, and in the Courtly habit, which so long she has longed for. And my Lord Lovelies Gamed with her.
His Lordship lay not at home tonight, neither at his Lodging, I heard that by the way. I cannot think my Lord and she both sate up all Night to see the Tailors at work, and to hasten the finishing of those Clothes, if she were with him which I would not be so unfriendly to inquire for the worth of a Wife. It was right honourably done of him to send her home as gallantly attended as attired, if she die a a lie with him all Night, which I will not be such a beast to believe although I knew it. I must come on her with a little wit though, for which I will precogitate.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Once more your story, for I am not satisfied with thrice being told it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Can a Woman take so much delight in hearing of another Woman's pleasure taken?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: As it was given by you I can, for I am prepared by it to take pleasure from you, and shall with greediness expect it till I have it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then know I pleased her so, that she protested, (and I believe her) her Husband never pleased her so.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Or any other man you should have put her to that, her Husband is but a Bungler.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I do but guess.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay she swore deeply, and I believed her there too; no man besides her husband but myself had ever enjoyed her, but let me tell you Lady, as she was amply pleased she may thank you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: For fencing you, I know she did and will.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That was the first respect, but not the greatest: For in our Act of love, our first and second Act

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In real deed, I can speak now like an emboldened Lover.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well, but what in your Acts of Love?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I had you still in my imagination, and that enabled me to be more grateful to her Ladyship, which wrought her thankfulness to you, expressed in a hundred pieces, sent by me, more than I could before, which are your own she says, since the other morning she was here with you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: That token confirms all. Had I the spirit of Witchcraft, when putting upon chance for my Revenge, to find Reward! Have you the money?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Safe at my Chamber for you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: O you are cunning, less I should break with you you thought to oblige me by it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I will rather run and fetch you twice the sum, I concealed it only to give it you unexpectedly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Sweet Bellamy I am yours, I could be sorry now I have lost so much of thee. This Kiss, and Name your time

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Would they had done whispering once, that I might enter safe in my manners.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Tomorrow night.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Shall you be ready so soon think you after your plentiful Lady feast.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O with all fulness both of Delight and Appetite.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And with all faith and secrecy I am undone else, you know my vows unto my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And can you think I dare be found your mean, to break them.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No more my husband comes. Pray Sir return my thanks unto my Lord for his right noble bounty, and not mine alone, for so my husband in much duty bound also, presents his thanks unto his Lordship.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Yes, I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I am your willing Messenger.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: He is my most honoured Lord, and has so many ways obliged me both by my wife, and in mine own particular that

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Still this is an Assinego. I can never get him to stand a Conference, or a Complement with me. But Sapientia mea mihi, what was that friend you made me send thanks for to his Lordship, what new favour has he done us, besides his council These Clothes, the cost was mine you told me, out of the odd hundred pound you took, what late Honour has he done us?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Is it not enough I know Friend? will you ever transgress in your impertinent inquisitions?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I cry you mercy friend, I am corrected justly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Will you never be governed by my judgment, and receive that only fit for you to understand, which I deliver to you undemanded? Do not I know the weight of your floor think you? Or do it you on purpose to infringe friendship, or break the peace you live in?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the sooner for a hasty word, I hope Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Did you not Covenant with me that I should wear what I pleased, and what my Lord liked, that I should be as Lady-like as I would, or as my Lord desired; that I should come, and go at mine own pleasure, or as my Lord required; and that we should be always friends and call so, not after the silly manner of Citizen and Wife, but in the high courtly way?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: All this, and what you please sweet Courtly friend I grant as I love Courtship, it becomes that bravely.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: O does it so?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p:
And I am highly honoured; And shall grow fat by
the envy of my repining Neighbours, that cannot maintain their Wives so like court ladies, some perhaps (not knowing we are friends) will say she is but Tom Salewares Wife, and she comes by this Gallantry the Lord knows how, or so. But Sapientia mea mihi, let the Assinegos prate while others shall admire thee, sitting in thy Shop more glorious, than the Maidenhead in the Mercers arms, and say there is the Nonpareil, the Paragon of the City, the Flower-de-luce of Cheapside, the Shop Court lady, or the Courtship Mistress, have my sweet Courtly friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How do you talk? As if you meant to instruct them to abuse me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To prevent that I will remove out of their walk, and keep shop no more.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the less for a hasty word I hope Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Fie, it is uncourtly, and now I will tell you Friend, unasked, what I have done for you besides in my late absence, and all under one.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Under one! yes, I could tell her under whom if I durst.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What is that you say Friend? methinks you mutter.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: No Friend, I was guessing what that other thing might be that you have done for me, all under one. You have taken the House I will warrant, that my Lord liked so.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: By my Lords favour and direction I have taken it, And I will furnish it so Courtly you will admire.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Must I then give up Shop, or lie so far remote?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No you must keep your Shop Friend, and lie here if you please.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And not with you but there?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No not with me at all Friend, that were most uncourtly.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: But I shall have a Chamber in your house, and next to yours. Then in my Gown and Slippers Friend at Midnight or the first Cock.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Softly for stumbling Friend, I will do you any honourable offices with my Lord, as by obtaining suits for you, for which you must look out, and find what you may fitly beg out of his power, and by courtly favour. But keep your Shop still Friend, and my Lord will bring and send you such custom, that your Neighbours shall envy your wealth, and not your Wife; you shall have such comings in abroad and at home, that you shall be the first head nominated in the next Sheriff season, but I with my Lord will keep you from pricking. Be you a Citizen still Friend, it is enough I am Courtly.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Here is a new Courtly humour, I see no remedy, unless I run myself out of credit, defy the life of a Citizen, and turn Courtly too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What is that you say? do you not mutter now Friend?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: No, not a syllable Friend, but may not I give up Shop and turn Courtly too Friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: As you respect my Lord, and your own profit, you must be a Citizen still, and I am no more a Citizens Wife else, and she must be a Citizens Wife, that must do all in all with my Lord Friends. Though my Lord loves the Clothes of the Court, he loves the diet of the City best Friend, what ever I wear outwardly he must find me Citizens Wife, which Friend, O he is a sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Well it shall be then as the sweet Lord will have it, Sapientia mea mihi.

div2.stage: ACT IV. SCENE I. Enter Lord Lovely, Crostill, Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Lady, it is true he is a bashful Lover, Unskilled to court a Widow, has not yet, The Act methodical to swear he loves you, Must and will have you, nor the moving boldness To stir your blood by putting of you to it, Or showing you how it is, before the Priest Declares it lawful. But he has love and sweetness, Which you will find with full and rich content; And look (look here) what a long, middle finger he has, Which with thin Jaws, and Roman Nose, Are never failing signs of Widows joys.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your Lordship is disposed to mirth;

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: It is My care to put you in a course of mirth, Nay of felicity.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: In marrying of that stripling!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Do not think slightly of him, though he appears Modest and bashfully, if I have any judgment, He is a fit match for you. His outward fortune For his estate, I will make good to him, And for his inward virtue never doubt He will make that good to you; However still He holds his much commended Modesty.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
My Lord you much commend his modesty, And bashfulness, urging your confidence Of his strange inward hid abilities (I hope your Lordships pardon) can you tell,
If he has with that bashful modesty Got any of his Mothers Maids with child? Or of his Fathers Tenants wives, or Daughters? I would have some assurance.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Then I will tell you. These Widows love to hear of manly acts, And choose their husbands by their backs, and faces.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: My Lord you said you would tell me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Yes, but I would not have you cunningly To sift discoveries from me to his wrong.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am loath to speak so plainly to you my Lord, But by the worst that you can speak of him I may the better like him.

sp.speaker: Lo.
Cros.
sp.p: You may as well suppose I will say it was well.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What say you to two or three!

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: The more the merrier.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: He has no less than five old Gentlemen's Young Wives with child this Moon, but got all in One week.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Yes, in good deed, and lusty.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Good deed call you it, to get other Men's Children?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Suppose they have the husbands consents.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I suppose they are wittols then.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: No they are wise alls, and it is a thing in much request among landed men, when old and wanting issue of their own, to keep out riotous Kindred from inheritance, who else would turn the Land out of the Name.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: An excellent policy!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You know the Lady Thrivewell.

sp.speaker: Cors.
sp.p: And her old husband, and his riotous Kinsman too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You will hear more hereafter, but now to him again, for whom I am spokesman.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: In a strange way me thinks.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: He is sent for far and near on those occasions, he is of so sweet a Composure, and such sure taking metal, that he employs my care to have him well bestowed before he begins to waste.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Is it possible he has done so much, and says so little?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: The deepest waters are most silent, But he can speak, and well to Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I have made your love known to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My love my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And have begun your suit; follow it yourself.

sp.speaker: Bel.
Lo.
sp.p: Which I will take off of you if you slight my care in seeking your preferment to this Lady, of beauty equal with her fair estate, in both which she is great, and her achievement will be the Crown, and the continuance of all my favours to you, you are lost if you pursue it not, I would thy old Uncle Bellamy saw thy Bashfulness.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your Lordship seems now to woo for me, not him, however I am bound in thanks to your nobleness, in your fair proportion, I hope, I shall not be so poor to require an advocate, when I shall yield to have a husband. But your mirth becomes your honour, and the young gentleman's reservedness him, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How mean you Mistress Crostill?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I do commend your mirth my Lord, for the lusty strain you spoke him in, that he had yet five children in one week, wherein I may presume you thought you had moved to my liking, ha, ha, ha

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I am glad I have made you merry, But you will wish if you reject him

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: If I reject one that tenders not himself! yet I commend his caution.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: As how I pray?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: As thinking I am one of your cast pieces (Knowing how well your Lordship loves the game) And now would put me on him, But you misprize me sinfully sweet Youth In such a thought, how ever you should not scorn To ride in your Lords cast boots, though you be Gentleman of his house.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Come now he shall have none of you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will hear him say he will not first, by your Lordships leave.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Spirit of contradiction!

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Stay sir, would you be content to have me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You heard my Lord say I should not.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But say he say again you shall, speak, will you have me?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Say no (I find her now) that is the way to win her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Without instructions good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p:
Lady I find so much your scorn already, That to be wedded to it, I should despair (My much unworthiness considered) to convert it Ever to love, and it is your love, before Your Person or Estate, that my affection Ought to direct me to. In answer therefore, to your will, you have me,
I must say no, till I perceive some sign Of love in you towards me.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Aye now he speaks! Some signs of love in me? How would you have it? Must I declare it to you, before you seek it?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No; I would seek it zealously, but my Lord Is off on it now, and I may lose his favour.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Is your love limited by his favour then?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Not limited: but (as it is as yet, But in its infancy) a little checked, Though it still grows, and may extend beyond All limitation to so fair an object As is yourself: But still my own demerit Curbs my ambition more than love emboldens.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: He speaks within me now.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Stay, let us retire. Here is the Lord Lovely.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Be he a Lord of Lords I will not retire a foot.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What servants Mistress Crostill do you keep, To let intruders in? O Master. Saveall!

div2.stage: Carless salutes Crostill, & puts by Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The humblest of your Lordships servants.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What Gentlemen is that you bring with you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: It is the Nephew of the good Knight Sir Oliver Thrivewell, of which Sir Oliver, I have procured unto your Lordship the sum which you desired by your servant Master. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: For that I thank him and you, but I could wish you had not brought that Nephew hither now.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Certes my Lord I am sorry.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: My reason is, I have entered Bellamy a suitor to the Widow.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: He also comes a suitor.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
And is in deep discourse with her already,
I will see fair play.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But you shall hear me Widow, and that to the point and purpose.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Lady at my request, do this Gentleman (who made the first approach) the favour to be heard, and answered first.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As his approach was first my Lord, she has heard him first already, and my request is to be heard now, and then let her answer both him, or me, or neither, what care I?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Your Name is Careless I take it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I came to talk with this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Pray my Lord forbear him, and let him speak, what do you say sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I say I love you, do resolve to marry you, and then to use you as I list.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I say I love you, do resolve to marry you, and then to use you as lift.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This to me Lady? I will take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Stay, I do but tell you what he says.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Take her at her word again sir, and I shall take you by the lugs. I say again you shall have none but me.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I say again, you shall have none but me,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, do you fool me, or him, yourself, or all?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Pray sir how old are you?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Are you good at that, pray sir, how old are you?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You press beyond your privilege, which is only to speak to the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: My Lord I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You may tell her so.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Let we beseech your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How can you use a Gentleman that loves you Dearer than Life, and only bends his study By all means to deserve you, one that (cannot?) Will not, while there are ways to die, live out of Your favour, with so much despiteful scorn, That when he speaks his soul to you through his lips, You make his Language yours, and give it a Boy?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What Gentleman is that you speak of?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The man that speaks it I am he.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: All this sir in effect, and more of my affection, can I speak to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Uns, but you shall not, you mistake the person to whom you are, or ought to direct your affection, you mistake strangely.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: No more than once a Lover, or at least, A bold pretender, having in civil language Expressed in writing his affection To a chaste Mistress sealed, and directed it, And on the contrary, courted his virtuous friend in brothel language; To a lewd strumpet. Have I hit you sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What can I say now! 'slife if that anger you after the error found, and confessed, I will write worse to you, and in earnest.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Master. Bellamy some other time I shall be glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Car.
Cros.
sp.p:
He looks with scorn at me, I must not lose him, yet dare not stay, for fear I tell him so.
I humbly crave your pardon good my Lord, Formy ill manners, and abrupt departure; The cause is urgent, and I beseech your mercy, Question it not.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Let your will guide you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Master. Saveall I thank you for my Suitor.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay but Lady.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes you shall control me in my own House.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I mean so too, but you shall woo me hard first.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: It is a mad Widow, which of these two now think you has the Better on it?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I think he shall in the end have the best my Lord, that can slight her most.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: It is my opinion too, and hear me

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, I have seen you but twice, and it has been at places where I cannot allow of your resorts, first at my Aunts, and now here at my Widows.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Widow sir! I thought she had been the Widow of one deceased.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou art a witty, pretty Child. But do you here use your wit, out of the smell reach of your Lords perfumed Gloves, and I shall take you by the Nose.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Forbear sir, I have a Handkercher.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And let me find you there no more, nor here I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I hear your charge sir, but you must leave it to my discretion to obey it, or not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Trust to your discretion!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And so commend me to my Lady Thrivewell. Come Bellamy away, what is your discourse?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: All fair and friendly my Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: So should it be with Rivals, fare you well Master. Careless.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your Lordships with a whew.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Will you walk homewards?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Excuse me sir I pray.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: It will not be convenient to return this day unto the Widow.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Fear it not sir, I like her not so well now.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Have you cross tricks Mistress Crostill? well I will got drink your Crotchets out of my Pate, then home, and do that which mine Aunt and I must only know. This is her Night of Grace, if she keep touch with me.

div2.stage: SCENE II. Enter Lady, Phebe, Closet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: In truth your story is pitiful, but your own folly has brought your scourge upon you.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: It was through the blindness of my love, and my credulity Madam, wrought by his strong Temptations.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, for this once I will strain a point of honour for you, chiefly indeed in answer of his rude unnatural presumption in attempting me. That a Villain can still be so barbarously lustful! If in this way I fie him not, and cause him to desist his beastly purpose, I will discover all to his undoing. Closet you know my mind, and full directions for the conveyance of our design.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes Madam, doubt not. Though I have but a naughty head at most, other matters, I dare not trust it for a sure one at such conveyances.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I presume to further the matter, he will come
home Drunk by his not coming to Supper.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Then he may forget what he so much expected, or sleep away his expectation.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: No, he will then be the more vehement till his desire be over.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You know his humour best it seems, away, away, my husband comes.

div2.stage: Exit Glo. Phe. Enter Thrivewell and Wat.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Well Wat, for this discovery I will make thy reward worth ten such masters services.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Sweet heart I have a suit to you But first what woman is that with Nurse?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A Kinswoman of hers whom she would prefer to me, but I have answered her, I will not charge your purse with more attendants; only I have given her leave to entertain, and lodge her this night.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: That is my good Girl.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now what is your suite sir, (as you are pleased to call it) which I would have to be your free command?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: It is for my absence from thee, to accompany Master. Saveall, to bring a dear friend on his way to Graves end tonight, who is suddenly to depart the Land.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: These sudden departures of friends out of the Land, are so frequent, and that I may believe you intend really, and no fained excuse; now will I think as long as you have good and substantial maid work at home, that you will seek abroad for any more slight sale ware.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: No more of that Sweet heart, farewell, expect me early in the morning.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I am glad of his absence tonight, lest there should happen some combustion in the house by his unruly Nephew, in case he should discover my deceit in beguiling him with his own wench instead of me, I do even
tremble to think upon the unnatural Villain, that would offer so to wrong his Uncle. I thought I had schooled him sufficiently, and beaten him off at his first attempt, and he to assail me again with more forcible temptations urging me to a promise.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: The young Gentleman is come in Madam, and as you foresaw very high flown, but not so drunk as to forget your promise! He is going to bed in expectation of your approach.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And have you put his Damsel into her night attire?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Most Lady-like I assure you Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And let her be sure to steal from him before Day.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes, with all silence Madam, she has promised.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: May Ladies that shall hear this story told, Judge mildly of my art since he is so bold.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nay but look you Master. Bellamy, it is not I protest that I am jealous, I make this inquiry for my wife. I jealous? I an Asinego then, I am as confident of my wife, as that she is in this house, how ever you deny her to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why Lady, you are not jealous now? If you were not, you would believe me she is not here.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
Without equivocation, Master. Bellamy, she is not here indeed, under your foot, but she is here in the house, and under somebody for aught anybody knows, but myself, that do confide in her as I say, and will
know no such matter, And so my Lord will be done with her, I hope I shall see her well tomorrow, and at her own house.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Can such language proceed out of any but a jealous mouth?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What an assinego is this! I say again, I do confide in her, not will I be dashed, or bashed at what any man says of, or against her; And therefore methinks it is very strange that you should deny her to me, that comes not to molest her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: There you are again. But since no denial will serve your turn, indeed she is here in this house, and in bed by this time.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Away, away, you mock i'faith, you are a wag she is no more here than I am, if she were here can I think you would tell?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How came you to think, or dream she was in this house at all?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I neither thought it, or dreamt it. Aye but sir, a waterman brought me a Letter in haste from one Master. Anonimus, intimating that my Ally was with a private friend at this house, and to lie here all night (a very likely matter) what private friend has she but my Lord, and that in a right honourable way, I confide in them both for that; but at this house is such a thing my Lord having divers Lodgings, and she a house of her own at his dispose and command, that is such a thing to be thought or dreamt on!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why came you to inquire then of such a thing?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Why sir, this Anonimus writ that I should come hastily hither, and ask to speak with you Master. Bellamy, and I should know further; hither I came, here I find you, you deny she is here, and what do I inquire any further?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You hear me say again she is here.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Go you are a wag again, she here? is my Lord here? or any private friend? alas, alas you are too young Master. Bellamy, and may as well persuade me I am jealous.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well sir, to put you out of all jealousy and doubt (if you be in any) I was the Anonimus that sent you the Letter to draw you hither and declare myself your friend, which shall instantly be manifest to you, if now you have a mind to lie with your own wife before any other man.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Then she is here indeed be like.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray come with me into the next Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: This is some waggery plotted by my wife, I smell it.

div2.stage: Exit. The Bed put forth, Alicia in it. Enter Bellamy, Saleware, with Light.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But you must be sure to say when she discovers you, that you came of your own accord, unsent for, as inspired or possessed by some Dream or Vision, to find her here.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Well, if this be not my wife's waggery in a main proof of her chastity, I am not here. I will do so sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So then, obscure yourself a while, while I approach her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It is I, your servant Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Sweet Bellamy, why come you not to Bed?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Does the love that was so hot, and the desire that was so fervent, begin to cool in you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good again, as if he an Assinego had ever made love to her fine waggery!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Has my mere consent to satisfy you, cloyed you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Consent to my Lords man, a likely matter!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Or did you court me to a promise only to try my fidelity to your Lord, and then betray me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Dear Lady think not so, but that I am struck into stone with wonder, and amazement at the most unexpected accident that ever crossed a Lover.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Dainty waggery this, what little mad Rogues are these to plot this to make me jealous?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray, are you serious? what is the accident?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I will not be so crossed, but kill him rather. To enjoy such a Mistress, who would not kill a horned beast? yet blood is such a horror

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Very pretty.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Will you not tell me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Speak lower gentle Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Why prithee, who can hear us?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I know not by what Magic your jealous husband has made discovery of our being here, he wrought sure with the Devil!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I am undone then. He will tell my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
I shall undo myself then Friend. No, Sapientia mea mihi. Be not dashed nor bashed for that good Friend, if there were any such matter: but this is waggery, fine waggery plotted betwixt you, to tempt my jealousy, but never the sooner for a hasty word I warrant you. Master. Bellamy that my Wife is here I thank you; But how I came to know it you shall never know from me; you sent not for me, I am sure you were not the Anonimus. Indeed it should have been Anonima Friend wife: for it was thy act I dare swear; However you do not hear me say I was sent, or writ for at all, more than by a Dream or Vision: But here I am and mean to remain tonight; I hope the house can afford you another Bed in it Master. Bellamy, and you to leave me to my own Friend wife, I like the lodging most curiously sweet Friend, and I prithee, lets thy heartily what luck
we may have in a strange place, I would so fain have a little one like thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I will leave you to your wishes, a good night to you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray sir a word first, husband be farther.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Faces about Tom Saleware, and march forwards.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You told me sir, of a hundred pound that your sweet Lady Thrivewell sent me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: It is true I have it for you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But she has since countermanded you to keep it, has she, and to mock my expectation of that, and you? why have you fooled me thus?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I rather should suspect your craft in this prevention: but love forbids me, and I must conclude, it is witchcraft in your husband.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Come let us kiss friends, and (sweet) tomorrow night I will prevent his Witchcraft, in the full enjoyment of our free pleasures: be you true to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: May all that is Man in me forsake me else.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Another kiss and then good night.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Are you still whispering? no matter, let them whisper.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Good night.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
Now may the spirits of all injured women, be added to mine own, for my revenge, which I this night will dream of slighted and mocked, he and his like shall know,
That when a yielding woman is so crossed, All thoughts but of revenge with her are lost.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: O he is gone Ally, Friend I would say, And now I prithee tell me how, or why thou camest hither.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Will you pardon me?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes faith, I were no friend else.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: It was but to try if I could make thee jealous.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In waggery! did not I say so! when do my prophecies fail?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But what brought you hither think you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A Letter from one Anonimus, but I will eat Spiders, and break if you sent it not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Give me the Letter.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Where is it? fecks I have lost it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: It was I indeed that sent it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Did not I say so too? and that it should have been Anonima, Sapientia mea mihi, when do my prophecies fail? I will to bed instantly while the prophetic spirit is in me, and get a small Prophet or a Soothsayer.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No, I will have no bedfellow tonight.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Ne'er the less for a hasty word, I hope Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I am at a word for that.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I will lie upon thy feet then.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well, you may draw the Curtains, and sleep by me.

p.foreign: Sapientia mea mihi, stultitia tua tibi.

div2.stage: SCENE IV. Phebe passes over the stage in night attire, Carelesse followes her as in the darke.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, sweet Madam, It will not be day these three hours, stay but three minutes longer, but a touch more, she is whipped into her Chamber. Could I but find the Dore I know my Uncle is from home O she returns with light: that is well.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What ail you! Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Would not any man be mad for losing such a Bedfellow? sweet Madam, let us retire without any noise.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What an insatiate beast are you? would you undo for ever both me and yourself?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not with one do more I warrant you, come away Madam, Madam, somebody knocks mainly at the gate; and I believe it is my Master returned before his time!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I cannot think it is he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It is the Rogue my man I warrant drunk, and has forgot I turned him away, but he shall spoil no sport. Come away Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Closet, go your ways down, and hark before you

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I will Madam

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: So now come Madam, I commend you in the charge you have given your watch woman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What charge do you guess?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why to tell my Uncle (if he be come) that he must not come near you, that you have had no rest tonight till just now you are fallen asleep, and so forth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Go you are a wicked fellow; I am sorry for any the least favour I have done thee, and do thou dare to attempt me once more, I will have thee turned headlong out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have got her with child tonight, with a spark of mine own spirit, and longs already to do me mischief. The boy will be like me, therefore it is pity to knocked on the head: But come Madam the other crash and good night, must I drag you to it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Touch me but with a finger, and I will raise the House.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You dare not sure, and now take heed you vex me not, have you not been my whore?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You dare not say so, for spoiling your fortune.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Faith but I dare, and if you will not obey me in a course of further pleasure tonight, fetch me a hundred pieces to take a course abroad withal, do ye look? I will make you fetch me hundred after hundred Housewife, when I want it, or shall be pleased to call for it. All comes out else, the gates of your fame flies open Lady, I will proclaim our Act.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Dare you forfeit your own Reputation so?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I shall gain Reputation by it in the company I keep abroad, and if the Cuckold my Uncle come to the knowledge of it at home, I shall possess him that you lustfully tempted me to it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Canst thou be so villainously impudent to destroy thine own fortune to ruin me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You may conceal all then, and so will I, and mend my fortune by yours, I will live bravely upon your fortune, and the heir which I have got tonight shall inherit it, my Uncles estate. And therefore indeed I would have all concealed; for my child's good, or rather for mine own: for it shall go hard if I put him not into a course in his minority to consume the estate upon me before he come to age.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And O that ever I did it!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou Villain, hast undone me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Come I will do you again, and then all is whole again; You are both undone, O you prodigious monsters That have betwixt you made me monster too! What is to be done, but that I kill you both, Then fall upon my sword.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Sir, you resume the temper of humanity, And let the Law distinguish you from them, You neither are to be their Executioner, Nor to fall with them.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Life to me is torment.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O the Devil, what a case am I in now!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray hear me sir?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Can more be said to aggravate thy shame, Or my affliction, than I have heard already?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Let me entreat you hear her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What shame did you, or what affliction I Suffer, when you discovered unto me Your bargain of a hundred pound in Saleware, You understand me. How was life a torment To me then think you?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Did you not vow forgements then? and thus, You freely would forgive my act? and thus Now to revenge it on me to my ruin, And your own endless infamy? O it is horrid.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: It is no revenge at all, only a show To startle you, or try your manly temper, And so near to be even with ye as to let you know, what some wife might perhaps have done being so moved, It was my plot indeed to strain you hither to this false fire discovery, for which I will give you reasons.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: O gross dissimulation.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Master. Saveall, you have done many fair offices for his Nephew, do this for me, entreat him to a Conference a few minutes in my Chamber; if I clear not myself in his and your opinion, and that by witnesses, let me be found the shame of all my Sex.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir, my counsels have been prevalent with your judgment, let me persuade you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: But I will have that friend thrust out of door first.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I would not that you should, nor give a look, or word to him till you have heard me; Then exercise your Justice.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Sir be induced to it.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You have prevailed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Go to your Bed again George, and sleep, be not afraid of Bugbears.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: How is this? She is come about again, and has patched all up already. I hope she will work mine Uncle to reward me for my Night work, and bring him in time to hold my stirrup while his George mounts her; She is a delicate well going beast! I know but one to match her in a course, just the same pace and speed as if I had only had the breaking, and managing of her myself, but the mark goes out of Phebes mouth now; and I will play my Aunt against all the Town. But how she thought to fright me with villain and impudent. And now go to bed George, ha, ha, ha, I find her drift. No wit like women's at a sudden shift.

div2.stage:
ACT V. SCENE I.
Enter Old Bellamy, Lovely.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Bellamy thou art welcome, and for thy Nephew I must ever thank thee, he is my best companion.

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p:
O my good Lord without boast be it spoken, I have ever been right and straight to your honour, and never did you an ill office in Man, Woman, or Child, what I have said of them they have proved at first, or I have wrought them to at last. But what do I speak on it, I
have ever been for your Lordship, all things I have sworn for you, I have fought for you, I have brooked for you, I have pimped for you, but what do I speak on it?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You need not Bellamy: for I know all.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: O the Gentlemen's Wives, and Farmers Daughters that I have presented to you in your Summer Progresses, and winter Journeys about the Countries. But what do I speak on it

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Because thou lovest to champ upon the bit to please thy old coltish tooth still, thou lovest the memory of the former sweets which now thou canst not relish.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: And here in the City, I have pledged more of your several Mistresses, than in my conscience there be honest Women in it. But what do I speak on it?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I never had so many man.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Or if you had, what do I speak on it? and in my conscience again, I have drunk more to your Lordships health in my days, than any Wine cellar in the City at this day, contains of Spanish French, and Rhenish; but what do I speak of that either?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: True Bellamy, fall then upon some other subject.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Yes, my good Lord, and I pray your Lordship tell me, does not my Nephew drink and wench pretty handsomely? I would fain have him take after me, and not his drunken father.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How well he shifts his subject, wicked old fellow!

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Does he not begin to fall to yet?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Not he.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Not a bit nor a soup? does he do nothing by example? or has your Lordship left it? or does he carry it like a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Discreetly and Virgin-like.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Pretty commendation for a young Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I would for my deserved love to him have put him upon a fair young Widow of a great fortune, but could not make him look upon her like a suitor.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
Lo.
sp.p: True Bellamy, speak of somewhat else.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: The Boy will ne'er grow up to me, I thought to have left him somewhat, I must discard him.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: If you do, he is in me provided for.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: What can your Lordship love him for?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Come I will tell thee, and be comforted. He has something of thee in him. He will pimp most conveniently.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: That is something indeed.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And for his modesty which is a rare benefit of nature in him, I dare trust him with a Mistress, as I would an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Benefit! A defect I fear, yet I may hope in time some Mistress of your Lordships may tempt, and bring him forwards.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: No I am confident Now your news.
Good Bellamy walk in the Gallery a while.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Some Mistress is coming to him, but what do I speak on it?
Go bid her come in.
What brings her so unseasonably?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Stay you at distance yet a while Friend, till I call you.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Faces about Tom Saleware.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How now! How is it with my love? Ha! How comes a trouble on this Face, where my delights are ever wont to Revel?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: O my Lord

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Say who has injured thee? Has thy husband taken up the uncivil boldness to abuse thee? or be it any other man, it shall be death, or an undoing to him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: My Lord, I am wronged, but would be loath to engage your noble person in my quarrel, some servant of yours may do it.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Of what condition is thy wrong? tell me; and who of my Servants thou wouldst have to right thee?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I would have Bellamy, how think you? is he faithful to you?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How canst thou question it? Has he not ever been so?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Your Lordship has well trusted him I know.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I do not know the man, I trust, or love so well.

sp.speaker: Al:
sp.p: But would your Lordship part with any Jewel, or choice thing you love, and have intended only for your own particular use, to him, or let him be your own partner in it?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Troth I think I should; only thyself excepted, but what is thy wrong I prithee, or wherein should Bellamy right thee?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Bellamy has wronged me to think me so unworthy as to be tempted to his lust; Bellamy has wronged your honour in that ambitious attempt.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Thou amazest me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And Bellamy must right me, and your honour; or you must cast off him or me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Give me at least some circumstance to make this probable.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Must not I be believed? you shall have instance then to make it truth, Friend Thomas. Pray verify unto my Lord the discovery you made last night of me, and Master. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: It was thus my Lord if it like your Lordship, my wife was forth at evening if it like your Lordship, as she may have often been if it like your Lordship, and may be as oft again if it like your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Well pray thee on.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Forth she was if it like your Lordship, I staid supper, and almost bed time for her if it like your Lordship; And had even given her over for all night if it like your Lordship, as I may of any night if it like your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: On I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Yes if it like your Lordship upon some private notice given to me if it like your Lordship, that she was at a private lodging if it like your Lordship, with a private friend if it like your Lordship, over I went, and found her abed if it like your Lordship, and Master. Bellamy even ready to go to bed to her if it like your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Is this true?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: As true as your Lordship lives if it like your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How could you be betrayed so?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: The Villain fetched me forth, and lodged me there as by your appointment, and for your own pleasure; but when it was late, and that your Lordship came not, thinking he had an advantageous opportunity, he soon discovers his love to me, and his treachery to your Lordship; I being in a strait only

(finding happy means, to send for my husband
to prevent him) made him a false promise being secure in my husband; and what had followed your Lordship understands.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I will ne'er trust man can blush and weep again.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In sooth if it like your Lordship I thought all had been but waggery if it like your Lordship, to tempt me unto jealousy, and my wife knowing well enough that I was by, bade Sweet Bellamy come to Bed. O Wag!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What messenger brought you the notice Master. Saleware?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A waterman my Lord, if it like your Lordship, here is the letter, if it like your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You told me you had lost it, when I asked for it to burn it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I thought I had Friend, but I found it now, and given it my Lord before I was aware Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Hell take that Letter.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now a bots on it for me, if thou beest angry Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You had better have swallowed it full of Ratsbane.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Ne'er the sooner for a hasty word I hope Friend.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Master. Saleware, if you will avoid a new addition of horns, come with this bearer over into Montagues close, where you shall find your Wife with a private Friend, at a private lodging; Haste thither, and ask for one Bellamy. Anonimus. What Riddles this? This is Bellamies own hand, I know it, why should he send to prevent himself? or how could she write his Character? This Woman is not right.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Do you note my art my Lord, to write as in a Man's Name, when I wrought it myself?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: And did not I tell you Friend, it should have been Anonima? Sapientia mea mihi.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Within there call Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: He is not within my Lord, and has not been tonight.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: His absence is another circumstance to a probability my Lord. But he was seen this morning to go in at Sir Anthony Thrivewels.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Go let my Coach be ready presently.
He should receive five hundred pound there for me, I trust he will not furnish himself with it for a flight.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: My Lord I gave you an inkling of a familiarity betwixt him and the Lady Thrivewell, he has since declared their act of lust to me, and urged it for an instance to my yielding.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Can you affirm this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes, to his face and hers.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: O Master. Saveall! welcome.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: My Lord your servant Bellamy is receiving your money at Sir Anthony Thrivewells.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: But my Lord, there is fallen an unhappy accident between Sir Anthony, his Lady and his Nephew, in which your servant Bellamy also is concerned; And your Lordship is much, and most humbly besought by the Lady to hear, and examine the difference.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I was preparing thither. O Master. Bellamy, you have not eavesdropped, have you?

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: Will you pardon me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Yes if thou hast.

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: I have my Lord, and am overjoyed to hear so well of my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You may hear more anon, come all along with me.

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: I may hear more anon, your Lordship though knows not of what so well as I do know.

div2.stage: SCENE II. Enter Thrivewell, Carelesse, Lady, Phebe, Closet, Wat.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I need not cast thee off, or bid thee go Now, and for ever from me, thine own shame Will force thee hence.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are deceived in that.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What is thine own take with thee, here it is all Phebe. Thou ever gettest, or canst expect from me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She was mine own before your wife became our coupler, in English plain our Bawd.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Use no uncivil Language while you are well.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: For which you have your witnesses, this false Traitor, that brought you on.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By my direction George.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No Traitor neither since you left to be my Master, wounded and turned me off.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And this dark Lantern here, this old deceptio visus, That juggled the wrong party into my Bed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Do you grin Grim Malkin? But sweet Madam, if your fine Springals Bellamy had lain there in my stead she would have brought the right party; your Ladyships Lily white self.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How is that?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No more of that good George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay, it shall out, since you have wrought my ruin, I will be the destruction of you all; And therefore now hear me O Knight, and first resolve to make me rich in my reward, for wonders I will unfold.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Canst thou expect reward from me for anything that can by thee be uttered?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Reward? why not? why should not you reward my good Offices as well as punish my ill? I must and will rely upon you for all the good that can befall me; or if I must expect no further from you, I will give it you gratis, And if you be anything but a Wittol hear me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To set you out livelier, than all your paintings: or dee hear will you give me a hundred pound a quarter for my silence?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not a penny; if you seek my undoing, heaven forgive you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What (Villain) canst thou speak to her prejudice?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That which (if you are no Wittol) you will be loath to hear, but you shall have it.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Darest thou talk so?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And since you hold my attempt at her, so heinous, you may be pleased to know I was incited to it by example of him I named, that smooth Faced Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Darest thou accuse her with him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You may ask her bolster there, her Madam Nurse old Mother Cock broth.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Aye, O you ask her sir, what she did with him, or he with her, in their two hours privacy in her chamber,
when he came to take up five hundred pound for his Lord, There was a sweet taking up, sir she confessed all to me, and on purpose, I dare be sworn to embolden me in my attempt to her Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I confess?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What did she confess?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That he made use of your Bed with your wife, what language shall I utter it in? you were best see it done before you believe it.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: O me most miserable if this be true!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Well, there is for them two.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Go Closet till I call you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now for that Rogue (because I must expect no further good of you, but this which is mine own you say) I will lay him open to you, you remember how once I ingratiated myself to you by rescuing you from a Robbery and Murder (as you supposed) for which you took me into favour

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Yes, and have wished a thousand times since, that I had lost the thousand pound I had about me then, and ta'en some wounds for it in exchange rather than by that rescue to have taken thy Viperous self into my bosom.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This Rogue plotted that business, it was a mere trick of his invention. The supposed Thieves were his companions, and wrought by him only to scare you and run away when we came to your succour, only to endear me to you. There was no hurt meant, but the slap I gave him over the Pate to colour the business, with little blood, I wish now I had cleft his brains.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Your wish though against your will is a good reward to him, for I love him the better for his wit in that plot, and care of his then Master.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Do you so sir? Then it was mine own invention, let him deny it if he can.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Indeed the plot was his sir, I only found the Actors.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I cannot condemn the conceit however; and am something taken with the wit on it, would all the rest were no worse.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And now I have uttered my whole mind sir, and you declared I must expect no further good of you, come away Phib, I have injured thee long, I will make thee now amends for all; I will marry thee, and sell Tobacco with thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Let him not go sir, I beseech you in this desperate way, nor till I answer to his accusation.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Sir you shall stay, and make yourself good before authority, or clear my wife.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You will have your house then known to have been a bawdy-house?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: The Courts of Princes and Religious Houses May so have been abused.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Under such Governesses.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You will anon be silent, what is the matter? we are busy.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mistress Crostill, Madam is come in great haste to visit you, and a Kinsman of your Ladyships with her.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: At such a time? excuse yourself.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They are here sir, entered against all resistance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Mistress Crostill! you have much honoured me Cozen Fitzgerrard! welcome.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: I have a private suit to you Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray Master. Thrivewell entertain the Lady.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Another sprunt youth.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sir, I perceive some discontent here, I hope your Nephew has not again displeased you?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: He is a villain, seeks my utter ruin.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Pray say not so, for fear you force me love him.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You are undone for ever if you do.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Do not say so, for fear I fly to him, The thought of him already breaks my sleep, I could not rest tonight for thinking of him, Which made my early haste to unload my mind, Presuming that your judgment may excuse A simple Woman's weakness, what is she That he courts so?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I tell you, she is a Whore with Child by him, lays claim to him, and I think he will marry her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Still you speak better of him, and my love must not see him so lost, sir let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Me Lady? I am busy; I am busy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
Car.
sp.p: I blush for you, what would you say now, were it not too late?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Nay only to your ear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Stand off a while Phih.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.p: His Lordship Madam shall give me accompt To each particular.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You shall do well to put it to him Cousin Husband, I overheard you, and commend you, That though you cast your Nephew from all hopes Of good from you, you will not yet destroy His fortunes other ways.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: For that I find by your reviling him You more inflame that cross fantastic Widow With eager love go cast herself upon him.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p:
Had I thought so, I had spoke well of him
Against my conscience.

sp.speaker: La.
Car.
sp.p: Tempt me not good Lady, To your own prejudice, your destruction; I am one you cannot live and lie withal A fortnight you, alas you are but a gristle, Weak picking meat; Here is one will hold me tack, Seven constant ordinaries every night, Noonings, and intermealiary Lunchings, At freedom every day, hold belly hold, The Cupboard never shut.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nor mind me Lady; It will be better for you. You had a thin chinned husband, played at Doublets with ye, And that perhaps, but twice or thrice a week, You are incapable of better Game, Here is one shall hold me Tick tack night by night, And neither of us guilty of a Why not, She is bred up to my hand, and knows her play.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Can you so slight me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Slight? I honour you. In caring for you to preserve your life, And your estate, which I confess myself Unworthy of: besides I am engaged To do a poor soul right for my issues sake She goes withal.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But say on composition she acquit you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O but conscience is conscience.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will die or have him presently. Can you refuse me for a prostitute whore?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Take heed what you say, I will shake your estate, If you dare call her whore before witnesses.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Call all the World to hear me Madam,
Sir Anthony, and the rest, be all my witnesses; Give me your hand sir, here before you all I plight my faith upon this Gentleman, He is my Husband, and I am his Wife.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You are then undone.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I care not sir, for your ill will: no more shall he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Are you catched Widow? Futre, for Uncles now?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why answer you not me, in troth plight?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I do, but yet I tell you again conscience is conscience; The Woman is not compounded with.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will give her a brace of hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: The Woman will not take it.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: The Woman shall take it, for now know sir, I love you not so ill as to undo you. This Woman has been mine as much as yours, she has done as much with me for Offices, and Service I have done for her, as she has done with you for Love and Money, let her deny it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have lately suspected so.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And if her Friends will make her brace of hundreds a leash I will marry, and honestify her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Honest Wat in good earnest I Gentlewoman with your hand give him your consent, and I will supply you with the odd hundred pound, for Wats love to his Master.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Will you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Yes, and with your allowance; it shall be in lieu of the hundred I took in Commodity of her Kinswoman Mistress Saleware, which would never thrive with me (as it may properly with them) as it was the price of lust you know it was, and how untowardly things have chanced amongst us since it was so; And now that
I have declined it, you shall see how sweetly all will be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Do as you please.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Go get you to the Priest presently, and bring him hither for thy Master, Wat.

div2.stage: Exit Wat. Phe. Enter Lord Lovely, Old Bellamy, Saveall, Saleware, Alicia.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Madam you sent for me, though I had former cause to require a conference with you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: My cause my Lord, is almost ended among ourselves. Pray let your former therefore be determined first, your Lordship may be pleased to sit.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I desire first by good Sir Anthony's patience, Madam a word with you in absence of all the rest, except this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: With all respect my Lord.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No you shall stay, and all the rest, speak openly my Lord, I do beseech you.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: My modesty forbids.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will speak it for you then; Good my Lord sit judge, This Woman comes to accuse me of incontinency with your servant Bellamy, is it not so?

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: Aye marry does she Madam to make her word good to my Lord that he would have lain with her too; And says that Bellamy affirmed to her that he did, Aye marry did he with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I have a Nephew here affirmed as much.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am sorry I said so much, it was but my suspicion in the days of my wickedness, I am honest now, and can think no such matter O is the parson come

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I fear I shall be wretched.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: You are wretched in your fear, note your wife's confidence; Can Guilt look with that Face?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I understand that Bellamy is in your house.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Forth coming my good Lord. Good Master Bellamy, fetch your Nephew, you will find him in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: And in this respect you shall give me leave My Lord to call your honour into question.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: you are very round with me Master. Fitzgerrard, What is your question?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Where is my Sister Amy?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ask you me?

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: Yes, and in honour you are to answer me, It is too evident, your courtship won Her Virgin honour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then I forced her not.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: The blame of that lay therefore on herself, That loss I seek not after: but I ask Her life and being (if she live or be) Of you my Lord, since it is manifest, She left her friends, and Country shortly after Her folly had betrayed her into shame, To be at your dispose, as we presume She is since in her two years absence; we Have sought all other ways in vain; you shall Do therefore well my Lord to render her, Or give me leave to urge you to an accompt Of what has become of her.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You cannot sure Compel me sir.

sp.speaker: Fitz.
sp.p: To hazard of my life I will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That she is lost I am grieved; But for your stout demand I will answer you at Weapons, time and place convenient.

div2.stage: Enter Old Bellamy, and Bellamy in a Womans habit, Closet.

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: I will end your difference Cousin Fitzgerrard, here is your Sister Amy my Lord, here is your servant Bellamy, whom I preferred to you as my Nephew, to be a Go betwixt you and Mistresses, which quality I now abhor, as I could wish your Lordship would leave Wenching for this inconstant Woman's sake that would be prostitute unto your servant. It was a flat bargain, and but a flat one, but for the non performance her husband may thank their party of Sex, not his wife's want of desire.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Ne'er the sooner for a hasty word I hope.

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: What further end she had to serve your Lordship she may relate herself.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Lost to myself, and friends being made unfit In any other Region to appear, And more unable to live other where; Than in the presence of my loved Lord (Although not as myself) I did assume That Masculine boldness, so to let you know My Lord, that I more fully could subsist By the mere sight of you, and so contain Myself, than she your more respected Mistress Could in the rich and plentiful enjoyments Of your most real, and essential favours.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sweet let us speak aside.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: What ails my Friend? is not all this now but a plot to make me jealous?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I am discovered and undone.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Ne'er the sooner for a hasty word I hope Friend. Come leave your waggery, is not all this but a plot now to make me jealous?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Your Plot good Mistress Saleware would not hold.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Nor shall it hold good Madam, I cannot be jealous, Sapientia mea mihi.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yet the young Gentleman (such as you see he is) has lain with me of old, before I was married; do not look so dismayedly, I will not detect you with my husband for a hundred pound

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Nor will I be jealous for a thousand Madam, your plot is too weak Fecks, but where is my injured Kinswoman, Madam?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O Phebe Gin crack! she is by this time righted, that is Married.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sapientia mea mihi, again then for that, that was my plot, and it held Madam.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My dear, dear Amy and my Bellamy, I do commend your vow of future chastity, Vowing the same myself, and here before Your Brother, and these friends to help your marriage I freely give you two hundred pounds a year During your life.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Now do you note the effect of all Sir Anthony?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I do with my much joy.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And Mistress Saleware, for your falsehood (Which I forgive, because you are a Woman) I quit familiarity with you, and advise you To love your husband, giving him no cause Of fear or jealousy.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Your Lordship counsels well.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Hang fears and jealousies, I would there were no greater in the Kingdom, than in Tom Salewares Coxcomb; But by your favour friend, we will be friends no more, but loving man and wife henceforward.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: That shall be as you please.

div2.stage: Musick. Enter Carelesse, Crostill, Wat, Phebe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
See new Married couples, please your Lordship
to take notice?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Uncle and Madam, I am come to call you to my house to Dinner, and your Lordship if you please, and all the rest here, I want one, my Rival Bellamy, where is he? we will be all friends today; and at night sweet heart, at night, at night, at night We will get the Boy that shall become a Knight

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You promise lustily.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: And Phebe if thou beest not better provided already, if I get not thee with Squire, let me turn clown.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But where is this Bellamy, what new Ladies that?

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: This new Lady sir, is that Bellamy you inquire for.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: The same Gentleman that you accused your Aunt with.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: That I confess had line with her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ha, is it so i'faith? and (now I think on it) in troth I thought so; would I have taxed her think you, but with a Woman? pray Master. Bellamy let me salute your lips, and good Uncle now we are Neighbours, and both good Housekeepers, let us not be strangers to one another.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Well sir, as I shall find you by your wife's report I shall be still your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I shall be his heir in spite of the Devil, and all his works and mine.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come Madam, I find here is Music, let us lead the Brides a Dance to stir their appetites to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And now my Lord to grace our Wedding feast, As you in honour are the greatest Guest You have full power to welcome all the rest.

sp.speaker: EPILOGUE.
sp.p: Well! had you Mirth enough? much good may it do you, If not, it is more than I did promise to you. It is your own fault, for it is you, not we Make a Play good or bad; and if this be Not answerable to your expectation Ye are the free born People of this Nation, And have the power to censure Worth and Wit, But we must suffer for what you commit. Yet we are resolved to bear your gentle Hands, And if you will tie us in any Bands, Let us be bound to serve you, and that is thus, To tell you truth, as long as you serve us.
